Proposed energy agency plans unveiled 

WASHINGTON (A P) — President 
( arter proposed Tuesday the creation of a Department of Energy to con­ solidate existing federal energy agen­ cies and to oversee the energy policies he will announce next month and that 

 he hopes Congress will adopt. 
The proposed new department will take over regulation of oil, natural gas and electric power and share with the 
Interior Department management of oil, gas. coal and other energy sources 
S p u r s 1 1 1 2 . 
■ s n ic k s 1 2 7 
Second straig ht w in — Page I ll 

 on federal land. 

Initial congressional reactions to his plans for the energy Cabinet post ap­ peared favorable although some possi­ ble controversy was anticipated over two key elements of the package. 
Sen. Abraham Ribicofr. D-Conn., chairman of the Senate Government 
Operations Committee w hich w ill review the proposal, announced he would introduce it in the Senate and that it will be co-sponsored by a number of prominent senators including Democratic leader Robert C. 
Bv rd. D W. Va. 
Carter’s proposal would create a new department with a staff of 19,767 and a fiscal 1978 budget of some $1o.6 billion. 

 absorbing entirely the present Federal 
Energy Administration (FE A ), the E- nergy Research and Development Ad­ ministration iERD A ), and the Federal 
Power Commission (F P O . 
Carter said the purpose of the proposed reorganization was to "give us one governmental body with suf­ ficient scope and authority to do the massive job that remains to be done*’ to cope with U.S. energy needs. 
James R. Sehlesinger, who is ex­ pected to head the new department if it is approved by Congress, said the con­ solidation would achieve greater ef­ ficiency but not necessarily reduce the number of government employes in energy programs. 

Sehlesinger said the bill was aimed at establishing a national framework for energy policy, not the policy itself. 
Sehlesinger said he hoped Congress would approve the new department by 
April 19. the day before Carter is to 

 send it a package of legislative energy policy proposals, but he recognized teat this would be a short timetable that might not be met. 
The new department would take over

Supreme Court affirms Frio’s apportionment 

By B IL L MINTZ 

In its first decision on Texas’ coverage under the federal Vot­ ing Rights Act, the U.S. Su­ preme Court has affirmed a new county commissioner apportion­ ment plan in Frio C ounty. 

'Although county officials did not challenge Texas’ coverage under the act.'the decision possibly could fore­ shadow a ruling on Gov. Dolph 
Briscoe’s challenge. 
The governor has sued the I S. Jus­ tice Department, saying Texas should not be covered by the Bet’s punitive 
Hellion. 
Texas was brought under those sec­ tions when the law was extended for in years by Congress in 1975. 
The punitive sections of the law re­ quire each Texas political subdivision to submit any election law change dating back to 1972 to the Justice De­ partment for approx at. 
Primaries blocked 
The Civil Rights Division of the Jus­ tice Department objected to Frio 
County's commissioner precinct plan and a three-judge court here blocked party primaries scheduled May I until a new plan was adopted. 
County officials and the Mexican- 
American Legal Defense and Educt- ttonal Fund agreed to a new plan calling for party primary elections 
Sept 2. 
But several county officials had an apparent change of heart and at­ tempted to withdraw from the agree­ ment. 
Hut the three judges — I S Circuit 
CtHirt Judge Thomas Ii. Gee and I S. 
Dist- Judges D. VV. Sultlc and John ll. 

Wood Jr. — said the new plan should stick. 
I tiller that plan, one Mexican- 
American and one Anglo were elected to the two vacant commissioners’ slots. 
Appealable 
A decision by a three-judge court is appealable directly to the U.S. Su­ preme Court. 
The high court issuini no written 

NEW YORK times service 
WASHINGTON - President 
Carter said Tuesday he expects to name a blue ribbon commis­ sion to study ways to curb the rising and “ almost uncontrolla­ ble" costs of m ilitary retire­ ment pensions and other man­ power costs in the defense es­ tablishment. 

( arter, answering questions Tues­ day from government employes and servicemen in the Pentagon as lie has done on visits to other departments. 
•did not flat Iv sa> he envisaged any reduction in allowances and benefits. 

But he said that in tile future “ our ability to defend ourselves might very well bi1 sapped away” by rising man­ power costs. lie described as excessive the pre­ sent system that permits servicemen to retire from active duty, take civ iliad jolts In the federal government and collect both their new salaries and much of their military pensions. 

This system. known as double dip­ ping. permits retired military person­ nel to earn far more than civ ilians in 

 comparable positions in the govern­ ment. 
In contrast, civilians who retire from 

 the federal government and are then 
.rehired by another government de­ partment — and who are called re­ 

 employment annuitants by the Civil 
Service Commission — are prohibited 

See CARTER, Page ISA 

3,1oo retirees in civil jobs here 

More than 3,11HI military re­ tirees are working in CMI Ser­ vice jobs in the San Antonio area, Ute U.S. Civil Service 
Commission reported. 

That figure represents about six lier cent of the Sun Antonio civilian gover- ment employes. It also represents about two per cent of the military re­ tirees employed in the nation by the federal government. 

C S . Air Force ret fries fill 1,965 slots. Civil Service Commistion infor­ mation officer Mary Ann Jimerson said 
Another I.(Kid retirees from the U.S. 
Army are working for the government here, she redried. 
Remainder 
Retired Marines and sailors account for the remainder. 
More than 49.(HH) people work in ci­ vilian government jobs in the Sun An­ 

 tonio metropolitan area, according to 
Civ ii Service Commission reports. 
Nationwide. 141 .IMH) military retir­ ees are employed by the federal go­ vernment, a Civil Service Commission report stated. 
The largest number of retirees — 
11.ooo — work in Washington, the commission report stated. 
Another 7.IHHI are working in the San 
Diego, Calif., area while about 4,IHM) retirees work in Norfolk, Va. 

Amendment to kill sick pay grandfather clause goes to panel 

(XRttUVCAMTOl HU*! AU 
AUSTIN — An amendment to re­ move a grandfather clause from the bill to repeal unlimited sick pay bene­ fits for San Antonio police and fire fighters was sent lo a House committee tiere Tuesday, 

The amendment, sponsored by Stutc 
Rep. Hon Bird of Sun Antonio, was endorsed by the original bin’s author, 
Sen. Frank Lomburdinn, also of San 
Antonio. 
It also bore the approval of Sen. Jack 
Ogg of Houston, who first tal ked the grandfather clause on the Senate bill before its passage by the Senate on 
Feb. 18. 
The House Intergovernment Affairs 
Committee is tentatively scheduled to take up SB459 sometime next week.

SB459 would repeal that portion of a 
1975 law which allows San Antonio po­ lice and fire fighters to accrue unli­ mited amounts of sick leave and take lumpsum payment upon retirement or jeux mg the department*. 
The repeal would apply only to San 
Antonio. Members of the Houston de­ partments would still be allowed to accrue unlimited sick leave for pay­ ment purposes. 
Ogg’s amendment provided San An­ tonio police and fire fighters covered under the 1975 law would receive full benefits for all accrued sick k*a\e until such time as the repeal bill was passed by this session of the legislature. 
Without the Ogg amendment, the 
San Antonio police anti fire fighters would be allowed to accrue only 9o days sick leave, and 6o days vacation time for cash payment. 
Lonibardino said Tuesday elimina­ tion of the grandfather clause takes the whole matter of this biti “ oui of the hands of politics. 
"Without the grandfather clause, the repeal returns the status of police and fire fighter’s sick pay benefits back to 
Die pre-1975 status. 
"T h at’s what the pepople of Sail 
Antonio said they wanted and the Bird amendment dm*s it.

In its first decision on Texas* coverage under the federal Vot­ ing Rights Act, the I*.S. Su­ preme Court has affirmed a new county commissioner apportion­ ment plan in Frio County. 

Although county officials did not challenge Texas' coverage under the act. the decision possibly could fore­ shadow a ruling on Gov. Dolph 
Briscoe s challenge. 
H ic governor has sued the I S. .Jus­ tice Department, saving Texas should not be covered bv the act s punitive section. 
Texas was brought under those sec­ tions when the law was extended for 16 years by Congress ill 1975. 
The punitive sections of the law re­ quire each Texas political subdivision to submit any election law change dating back to 1972 to the Justice De­ partment for approval. 
Primaries blocked 

The Civil Rights Division of the Ju s­ tice Departm ent objected to F rio 
County's commissioner precinct plan and a three-judge court lu re blocked party primaries scheduled May I until a new plan was adopted. 
County officials and the Mexican- 
American Legal Defense and Educa­ tional Fund agreed to a new plan calling for party prim ary elections 
Sept 2. 
But several county officials had an apparent change of heart and at­ tempted to withdraw from the agree­ ment. 
But the three judges — l .S. Circuit 
Court Judge Thomas (J. Gee and I S 
Bist Judges D VV. Suttle and John ll 

Wood Jr. — said the new plan should stick. 
Ln d er that plan, one Mexican* 
American and one Anglo were elected to the two vacant commissioners' slots

MTV icemen in the Pentagon as he has done on visits to other departments, did not flatly say he envisaged any reduction in allowances and benefits. 

But he* said that in the future ability to defend ourselves might very well In* sapped away" bv rising man­ power costs. 

He described as excessive the pre­ sent system that permits servicemen to retire from active dun, take civilian jobs iii the* federal government and collect both their new salaries and much of their military pensions. 

This system, known as double dip­ ping. permits retired military person­ nel to earn far more than civilians in

Serv ice Commission — are prohibited

Convict wants death on TV 

A m an a w a itin g death in the electric chair in Albany. N Y., says his execution should be televised to dramatize the barbarity of capital punishment. 
“ I feel any person in his right mind wouldn't want to die." con­ victed killer Joseph J am es said in an in te r v ie w w ith th e A lb an y 
T im es-l’nion. “ But if society wants to condemn m e to death. I'd love to have the w h o le th in g te le v ise d , especially by u sin g the barbaric electric chair. 
Jam es. JU, of New York City. was sentenced to die for killing New 
York City policem an George Mot- chan oil Sept. 9, 1975. His scheduled 
Jan. 9 execution was stayed pending an appeal

Strange catch 

When com m ercial fisherman 
Melvin Sousa em ptied his nets on the dock last week in F’ort San Luis, 
( alif., he found flounder, sole, rock carp — and a water-logged wallet. 
II. Dieter Heinz of Shell Beach, nearby on the central C alifornia coast, said he dropped the wallet over board last August while fishing from a sm all boat in about 29o feet of water lour m iles offshore. 
Heinz’ credit cards were still in tin' w allet w hen Sousa found it. 
M issing and presum ably disinte­ grated w ere his driver's license, family snapshots and a $2o bill. 
"T his isn t the w eirdest thing we've dragged up," said Sousa, 
'k ip p e r of th e b o tto m tr a w le r 
Sidewinder. Several years ago his nets snared a parachute and hel­ met. he said.

Horsesense lawyer 

Larry Denny shod horses while he learned to be a lawyer. He likes to think he picked up som e h orse­ sense that way. 
The 3o-year-old D ayton. O hio, bachelor paid his way through law school in K entucky with m o n ey earned shoeing horses. 
“ Shoeing horses and practicing law are a lot a lik e,” he say s of his two professions. 
“ Both the horse and the client has a p ro b le m to be a n a ly z e d and 

 sob od. 
Denny lea rn ed to shoe h o r se s while a college student near Dan­ ville. Ky. By the tim e he finished law school he had a b la ck sm ith business that took him from coast to coast. 

His pijst as a sm ithy helps m ak e him a better law yer. Benny says. “ I feel I relate better to people. I don't feel I'm stuffy and co n serv a tiv e acting like most a ttorn eys.”

 r e m a in e d an u n so lv ed m y s te r y for more than six years.

Restless

1971: “ He ( H u g h e s ) w a n ts b e k n o w from ('bester how long this IRS thing will keep us out of the country.” 
Chester is the billionaire’s abrasive lawyer. Chester Davis. 
The f ch ow ing year, H ughes changed penthouses again to the Intercontinen­ tal Hotel in M anagua. Nicaragua. 
Then an earthquake forced him sud­ denly to flee on Dee. 23, 1972. He took th e r isk of la n d in g in M ia m i but changed the destination in m idnight to 
Ut. Lauderdale to confuse the author­ ities.

_______ th e flig h t p la n . So he had a g en ts w a itin g at Fort L au­ derdale with a subpoena for the elusive Hughes. 
”

Johnnie W alters and A ssistant C om ­ m issioner John Halon. 
Files 
Through our own Hughes in vestig a­ tion. m eanw hile, we gained access to his private files and arranged for the 
IRS to photograph them . 
T h ese show his p erson al financial em pire was valued over $2.3 billion. 
It includes seven liotel-casinos, 1.299 m ines, un airline, a m unitions works, a s s o r te d t e l e v is i o n p r o p e r t ie s and 
.KUMM) acres of undeveloped desert. 
The Nevada casinos alone frequently handle m ore than SI million in a day of wagering. 
The billionaire controlled m ost of his o p e r a tio n s th ro u g h th e L as V e g a s- b a sed S u m m a C o rp ora tio n and the 
M iam i-based Howard Hughes M edical 
Institute.

T he year before he died, for e x a m ­ ple. Su m m a a m assed $182.4 m illion in savings and liquid investm ents. 
Yet this w as a decrease, the records disclose of $32.5 million from the pre­ vious year.

H ughes w as short of ca sh “ to cover nonoperating and non­ recurring costs."

New census

When the bureau reports new ethnic breakdowns, the co m m issio n ers could develop a new precinct plan subject to approval by the Civil Rights Division of Hie Justice Department.

CHItf. IXPBSSS CAPITOL SURF »U 

AUSTIN - The Rev. Claude 
Black, San Antonio city council­ m a n . and fo r m er S tate Rep. 
Maury Maverick dr., led a par­ ade of w itnesses here Tuesday testifying for a bill to abolish the death penalty in Texas. 
B lac k an d M a v e ric k w e r e a m o n g five San Antonians who appeared be­ fore a joint hearing by the House and 
Senate Criminal Ju r is p r u d e n c e C om ­ mittees. 
Hearings were being held on HH 563 by Rep. S am Hudson of Dallas, and 

HBs 5H8 and 913 by Rep. Joe L. Her­ nandez of San Antonio. 
Hudson’s lull calls for the complete abolishment of the Texas death penalty law. 
H ernandez’s HR 568 calls for a un­ animous vote of the five-judge Texas 
Court of Criminal Appeals in order to uphold a death sentence appealed from a state district court. 
I IB 913, by Hernandez, would extend the sta te 's capital m u r d e r law to in- elude peace officers who kill a person in their custody. 
After hearing nearly five hours of testimony on all three hills, the House com m ittee referred them to subconi- mil tee for further study.

 the circum stances and needs tor each county. 

The orders for Bexar. Comal, Hays, 
Medina and Kendall counties will re ­ main virtually the sa m e as under the present order. 
The proposed orders for Uvalde and 
Kinney counties have been weakened from the present order. 
Notzon and Reeves will contend the present o rd er should be m aintained. 
They said enforcement should be uni­ form throughout the seven counties. 
Notzon sa id T u e s d a y m o s t of th e state s regulations concern controlling d e v e l o p m e n t w h ic h m a y h a r m the aquifer water supply. 
Such re g u la tio n s would not affect 
U valde aud K inney c o u n tie s or any rural area tint ti development occurs iii those areas, Notzon said. 
Concern 
Ile added there is concern, especially by the state attorney general s office, that splitting the order may have the regulations struck down by the courts as discriminatory. 
Y a n t i s ’ pro p o sal is his second a t ­ tempt to change tile order.

TWQB from taking action. 

Black, who is also pastor of the Mt. 
Zion First Baptist Church in San An­ tonio, told the c o m m itt e e s Ik* was testifying as an individual "opposed to capital punishment on the basis of the sacredness of life 
"I am testifying because I don’t want to la* a particip ant in uphold in g the state iii the m a tter of putting someone to death.” Black said 
Black, who traced the death penalty through history, told the joint c o m ­ mittees “ there is something essential­ ly wrong vvih a society that feels it has the right to put someone to death.” . 
Black also attacked the inequity of the death penalty which he said is in­ flicted mostly on the blacks, browns and poor whites. 
“ T h ere is in equity u n d e r th e law which allows people of higher econo­ mic status to escape capital p u n is h ­ ment while inflicting it on the poor and the minorities. 
He defined capital punishment as " t h o s e who lack the capital get the punishm ent.” 
History 
Maverick also gave the committees a history less*rn which Included several members of bis own family who helped frame past laws in Tex,is. 
’’We in T e x a s h a v e a h i s t o r y of landing on people who are poor, people who a r e b la c k an d p eo p le who a r e brown," Maverick said. 
" M y own a n c e s t o r s h av e h elp e d create some of the travesties we are here today t r y i n g to do s o m e t h i n g about." 
Maverick term ed the death penalty cruel and unusual punishment "when it s appl led to anyone because of race, color, creed or social sta tus.’’ 
He told the legislators, "this is our last chance for state’s rights as well us states’s duties.” 

His t e s t i m o n y w a s g r e e t e d by applause from the nearly full House chamber and gallery. 

San Antonio attorney Pat Priest, who d e f e n d e d c o n d e m n e d San A n to n io slayer Donald Eugene Franklin who is now on Huntsville’s death row, te sti­ fied for HH 568 by Hernandez. 

He called for passage of the bill lo provide for a u n a n im o u s vote of five 
Court of Criminal Appeals on the death penalty. 
Judge 

" I t s t r u e , " P riest said, “ this bill would allow a single judge to, in effect, nullify the d eath penalty ’aw by his vole on this court. 

“ But these judges are elected every six years allowing th e voters to both express themselves on tin* death pen­ ally as well as the actions of a parti­ cular judge.” 

A letter from the Rev. J i m m y R. 
Allen, pasto r of San Antonio’s First 
Baptist Church was also read into the record favoring the Hernandez bill. 

M a y o r a l c a n d i d a t e J o h n 
M onfrey e ith e r b e lie v e s in l i v i n g d a n g e r o u s l y or Ik * knows so m e thin g the rest of us haven't figured out. 

 question that has puzzled Sun 
Antonio political pundits for several m o n th s is: Can C o m m u n iti e s O r ­ ganized for Public Service and the 
A quifer P ro te c t io n Assn. s ig n i fi­ cantly influence elections of public officials? • 
Judging fron Monfrey's re m a rk s to the G reater San Antonio Builders 
Assn. Monday night, he has decided t h a t C O P S a n d APA a r e p a p e r tigers — at least as far as the up­ coming mayoral race is concerned. 
The San Antonio b u s i n e s s m a n went out of Ins way to provoke both groups. 
Foot the bill 
First, he advocated that tin- city loot the bill for extending utilities to development sites outside tin* city limits. 
( O P S has done e v e r y th in g but t e a r down Citv Hall and ta r and leather the City Water Board trying to force city officials to m a k e d e ­ velopers pay for such extensions. 
T h e o rg a n i z a t i o n w a n t s W a t e r 
Board money used to improve the water system within the city limits. 
Monfrey not only poo-poocd that idea, but he also let the builders know lie was on their side in tin* s q u a b b l e w ith t h e 
APA o v e r whether development should be al­ lowed over the Edwards Aquifer. 
Specifically, he said if engineers indicated it was okay to build over the aquifer, he would favor such construction also. 
W hile that m i g h t s e e m like a r e a s o n a b le a t t i t u d e to s o m e San 
Antonians, the e n v i ro n m e n ta lis t s see such a position as a potential threat to the aquifer. 
They have about as much faith in en g in eers, pa rtic u la rly the T ex as variety, as they do in developers. 
Leery 
Prior to the I BTH referendum on zoning for a mall over the aquifer, the p r o -m a ll fo rc e s p a r a d e d n u ­ merous engineers before the public t»* assure citizens that their water supply was not in danger. 
The aq u ifer protectionis ts have been leery of engineers ever since 
A pparently Monfrey figures he can fade whatever heat he catches from APA and COPS and still col­ lect en o u g h v ote s to win th e v: 

 mayoral race lie may be right. 
COPS’ by-laws forbid endorsing c a n d i d a t e s , so M o n f re y d o e s n 't have to worry about organized op­ position from that quarter. 
APA does endorse candidates, but thus far its vvin-loss record hasn't been very impressive. 
Both organizations are strongest in issue-oriented c a m p a i g n s , and they may simply bi* unable to have m u ch im pact on p erso n a lity eon- test s. 
Monfrey b ette r hope t h a t ’s the case.

Kuchen Sandoval, a Sun Antonio at­ torney who bas recently figured pro­ minently in a controversial case, testi­ fied for the Hernandez bill on peace officers. 

Sandoval represented tin* family of 
R ich a rd M o ra le s who w as s la m by f o r m e r C a s t r o v i l l e T ow n M a r s h a l l 
Frank Hayes.

T uesday ap p ro v e d s u b ­ mission to the Texas Le­ gislature of a law change allowing it to purchase and sell surface water.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesdoy March 2 1977 

Get ready for spring by starting at the 

No timidity, Carter tells Bukovsky 

W A SH IN G T O N (A P ) 
— President Carter told 
Soviet dissident Vladimir 
K. Bukovsky at a White 
House meeting Tuesday that he w ill not be 
“ timid’ in his pronoun­ cements on human rights and that the 
U.S. 
“ com m itment to Hie 

 concept of human rights is permanent.’’ 

But Carter said he wants his public sta­ tements on human rights to be “ productive and not counterproductive.” 

In tile face of strong 
Soviet protests over 

C arter’s human rights pronouncements, the 
I*resident told Bukovsky that lie wanted “ to assure that our own nation and countries other than the 
Soviet Union are con­ stantly aware that we want to pursue the freedom of individuals 

 and their right to express themselves.” 
Carter's 1o-minute vi­ sit with Bukovsky in the 
Roosevelt Room, across a hallway from the Oval 
Office, was in marked contrast with former 
President 
Gerald 
R. 
Ford s refusal to meet 

Soviet dissident A lex­ ander Solzhenitsyn. 
But the White House has been sensitive to the way the Bukovsky meet­ ing is viewed and refused to allow photographers and reporters into the meeting for even a brief period.__________________

Carter opposes reviving draft 

•WASHINGTON (AP) — President 
Carter said Tuesday he has no present intention of reviving the m ilitary draft, but left open the possibility that such action might be necessary in the fu­ ture. 
Speaking in the Pentagon's open air court before several thousand of the 
22.ooo m ilitary personnel and civilians who work in the building. Carter said that if a return to the draft should be considered in the future “ my inclina­ tion would be to make it comprehen­ sive," with no special exemptions such as college deferments. 
The President said that Defense 
Secretary Harold Brown and the Joint 
Chiefs of Staff are now assessing the effectiveness of the all-volunteer force recruiting. 
Not yet 
His firs t words in response to a question about how he feels on the is­ sue of going back to the draft for the regular services or the m ilita ry re­ set \ es. Carter said, “ That's a decision that's not yet been made." 
However, he added. “ At the present time. I have no intention of going back to a mandatory draft law.'* 
The questions from Pentagon per­ sonnel massed in front of him dealt mostly w ith personnel and related matters and never touched on such cosmic issues as nuclear policy or for­ eign affairs. 
The reception was friendly and his remarks were interrupted a number of times by applause. 
In a b rie f talk and in answer to questions. Carter made these points: 
Draft evader pardon — he believes that “ we can count on American c i­ tizens to serve their country" readily in the future regardless of his decision to pardon Vietnam-era draft evaders. 

“ I don't have any apologies to make" for the draft evader pardon. 
Carter said. 
M ilita ry unionization — The P re­ sident said it is his “ strongly held" opinion that “ it would not be advisable to have the m ilitary unionized." 
He said he does not believe that any new legislation is needed to prevent such unionization, and that no national labor union leaders have indicated to him that they intend to launch a cam­ paign to sign up m em bers of the armed forces. 
Wall of water kills miner, 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesday March 2 1977 

 trap 8 nine 

TOWER C IT Y . Pa. (A P ) - A three-foot-high wall of water rushed through a tunnel in a coal mine Tues­ day. killing one miner and trapping at least nine others, a mine official said. 
The miners were trapped in the tun­ nel I Vi m iles into tile side of a 
4oo-foot-high mountain. There was no immediate word on their condition. 
Leon R ichter, vice president in charge of deep mining for the Rocher 
Coal Co., said other mine employes were conducting rescue operations, searching through the m ine and remov ing debris. 
About IOO workers were reported in the mine when the w ater rushed through the tunnel. At least three miners were admitted to a hospital. 
The accident occurred at 12:3o p.m. in the Porter Tunnel of Kocher’s anth­ racite mine in Schuylkill County, state police said.

Miss Cariaga’s voice is like raw honey 

By B K N K IM ; lr 
It sounded like soprano 
M arve le e 
Cariam a downed a pint of raw honey before her 
Tuesday reeital — her voice was that smooth and natural. 
And besides treating her T u esd a y M u sic a l 
Club audience to an ex­ traordinary voice. M iss 
Carlage proved a classi­ cal m usic recital doesn't have to be a b o rin g 

Review 

 seat-squirming affair. 
Before each song. the soprano explained what 
(hey were about and wasn't above m aking a few jokes or pointing out a .Sesame Street c h a r­ acter also sings one of the arias on her program. 
But the m ain aspect se tting M is s C a ria ga apart from most other singers is her extremely natural voice. 
She doesn't try to im press her audience by showing how close she can come 

 to stra in in g their oae d r u m s with her rang‘d and volume. 

Instead, her voice, which was clearly audi­ ble throughout the recital hall, searches out the nuances in her repertoire which runs from Mozart to ‘Jhth C entury co m ­ posers. 

Coupled with 
Mi s > 
Cariaga’s unaffected vo­ calizing is her sense of drama. When she sings an aria, she doesn't for­ get the lyrics have a meaning beyond the m u­ sical notes.

(PG) 

By RON WHITE 
“ Rocky” is schmaltz with punch. 
The heavyweight con­ tender for 
Academy 
Awards is a fairy tale wrapped in a veneer ot street-tough shabbiness and grime. Disguised as realism, “ Rocky” is at heart a soft-mined fan­ tasy directed so crisply and smoothly by John G. 
Avildsen that a viewer can realize he’s being suckered by the film and 

LIVE...ON STAGE! 

...w o n d e r f u l ; 
ENGROSSING i 
BRING ONE OF 
A 
BELOVED 

STAGE EFFECTS

LITERATURE S MOST 
HEROES TO LIFE ON 
THE STAGE.

TH U RS., M A R . 3, 1977 
8:3o P M cQSsatrefotrtlje cP erform ingcjA rts 

 lichen* on kale al JiMtke a downtown and N orthn U r M all. 

Boc office open all da> of perform ance. 

 still wind up cheering. 
The film comes out of a real-life fantasy, a script written by Sylvester 
Stallone, before “ Rocky” a bit player in undistin­ guished films. 
Stallone wrote the script about a not-too- bright bum of a prize­ fighter who, despite his record and all logic, gets a chance to fight the heavyweight world champion. Stallone wrote the script with himself in mind for the lead and resisted efforts to put name stars such as Burt 
Reynolds or Ryan O'Neal into the role. 
His determination paid off. Not only has Stallone received a Oscar nomin­ ation for best actor (one of IO nominations for 
“ Rocky ”), but, along with Avildsen’s direc­ tion. 
Stallone is 
“ Rocky's” major asset, a charming, and fascinat­ ing actor who creates a perfect underdog, sym­ pathetic and likeable, the kind of character who gives a fairy tale its ap­ peal. 
Has-been 
Rocky Balboa is a has-been without ever having been anywhere in the first place. He can earn -SJO when he wins a fight with another has­ been in a small ring in 
Philadelphia. But he earns more money being a bill collector for a loan shark — another job he’s not likely to succeed at because he’s too soft­ hearted to deliver collec­ tion notices by breaking thumbs. 
He lives in a dingy, noisy apartment with a goldfish, two turtles and a poster of Rocky Nlari- ciano. Ik* tries with his inarticulate mumbling and bad jokes to flirt with a shy clerk at a pet store 
(Talia Shire). 
His character is made up of small slices of rea­ lism — flashes of anger when he’s hurt in the ring, boyish bashfulness, manly indignation when he finds out his gym locker has been turned 

E igh t harps d u e at SAC. 

The melodious sounds of eight harps playing simultaneously va ii I be featured at two free pro­ grams this week at San 
Antonio College. 

The Harp Ensemble of the University of Texas at Austin will present programs al 
8 p.m. 
Wednesday and ll a.m. 
Thursday. Both perfor­ mances will be in McAl­ lister Auditorium. 

R e v je w 

 over to someone else ana muffled depression when the gym s manager 
(Burgess Meredith) tells 
Rocky he took away his locker because Rocky has become a sap. a bum, a lighter who never lived up to his potential. 
That potential, hinted at several times, is tile crux of the film. Rocky is likeable enough when the chance comes for him to make it big. the viewer is 

 in there rooting for him. 
And the chance comes when the black hea- vvweight champion (Carl 
Weathers), a Muham­ mad Ali-styled showman, finds himself without a march for a scheduled bout. 
Cynically drawing upon America's tradition as “ the land of opportun­ ity.” the champ decides to light an unknown and choses Rocky because he’s while and because the champ likes his nick­ name. “ The Italian Stal­ lion.’' 

For the champ, the fight is to be a show 
Miracle 
But for Rocky ifs a miracle, a chance to prove he's not a bum. He doesn t expect to win. He lust wants to stay in there for the whole fight with a boxer no one has ever stayed w ith for more than three rounds. 

There is a point in 
“ Rocky” when the film hints at being much bet­ ter than it is. After the bout is announced Mere­ 

 dith comes to Rocky s 
But suddenly Rocky apartment telling him runs after him. The sap what he needs is a has risen to the'occasion manager, someone like and Rocky gives tho old himself w ho's spent 5o man a chance he doesn’t years in boxing and can deserve any more than show Rocky the tricks. 
Rocky deserves a chance 
Rocky indignantly at the title chews out 
Meredith. 
The genre of fairytale 

Where was he HI years ago when Rocky was starting when his advice might have helped? Ile doesn't need him now and 
Rock v s angry shouting echoes down the dark, littered street as the old man shuffles away. 

 has been resurrected, gi­ ven a shabby but beauti­ fully fitting set of se­ cond-hand clothes and pushed into a fixed fight. 
And Iikt* a fixed fight, wintling on merit isn't as important as the illusion of winning, which is what a fairy tale creates.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesday Morch 2 1977 
Few turn out for Austin’s gas hearing 

By DICK MERKEL chih. rmtss capitol auw-xij 
AUSTIN — Austin's public hearing on the proposed settlement agreement between Coastal States Gas Producing 
Co. and its customer group, came off without a hitch Tuesday night. 
It also came off without the public. 
Fewer than 5o people showed up for the meeting in Municipal Auditorium. 
They were almost outnumbered by the press, the city council and an assortment of other city employes. 
Only three people in the audience chose to make statements and an obviously disappointed 
Mayor .Jeff 
Friendman called a halt to the meeting 
55-minutes after it started 
Forum 
Friedman opened the public forum by assuring the scant audience “ there w ill be no decision. I repeat no de­ cision. made here tonight 
The mayor added In'" assurance thai 
“ regardless of what happens with this settlement — whether ifs accepted or rejected — this w ill not mean gas prices are going down 
“ About all it can assure, if a settle­ ment is agreed on. is a continuity of future gas supply." 
Butler laid much ot the blame for the present situation on the doorstep of the state Railroad Commission 

Butler said there were only three reasons a settlement with Coastal and its subsidiary' Lo-Vaca Gathering Co. should be considered. 
“ Gno.“ he said. “ is the small chance we would ever be able to collect even a small part of our damages from law­ suits now pending. 
“ The only alternative would be to force CoastaI/Lo-Vaca into bankruptcy and this could only lead to wholesale disruption of gas service. 
“ Gas prices aren't going down. but a settlement would at least assure.us of some continuity of supply," Butler said 
The trio of citizens who did express views Tuesday night were in agree­ ment on one point. 
While only one mentioned him by name, all three said they wanted Oscar 
Wyatt. Coastal Board chairman and majority stockholder, out of the pic­ ture. 
. 
One man said: “ I'm here represent­ ing my wife and she wants a pound of 
Oscar Wyatt's hide." 
To this Friedman replied, “ she might have trouble. I understand 
Wyatt's villa on the French Riviera is well guarded.” 
Another said he felt “ the entire settlement plan is the work of the big, private utility companies and they are my natural enemies " 
Dist. Atty .-designate plans staff changes 

By ALAN BAILEY 
Dist Atty.-designate Bill White said 
Tuesday he plans new staff appoint­ ments soon atter he’s sworn in as the new Bexar County chief prosecutor. 
White said he spent some time 
Tuesday talking with staff members about restructuring the district attor­ ney's office. 
But White said he would make no announcements until after he's sworn in which should be within the month. 
White also said he planned on “ being around when the next election time comes but would not make any formal announcement at this time. 
White expressed happiness “ about the confidence the governor had in appointing me. I'm looking forward to being the district attorney for the loth laruest city in the V S 
“ I ’vt* been up here for l l years now in the D.A.’s office and I'm looking forward to trying to work for the citizens of the county to get rid of the criminal element we have here." 
White replaces Dist. Atty. Ted 
Butler, w ho has been upturned to the french by Gov. Dolph Briscoe. 
Butler also said he would like to thank the governor. 
“ I'm extremely grateful to Gov. 
Briseis for having appointed me dis­ trict judge and grateful to Sens. Frank 
Lonibardino. Glenn Kothmann and 
John Traeger for the important part they played in my appointment. 
“ I would also like to express appre­ ciation to the people of Bexar County and the media for the support they have given me and my staff during the past seven and a half years 
“ I am ever grateful to my hard working and loval stall for the won­ 

 derful job they have done during that time." 
The appointments are effective April 
I 
C a r te r g ets n e w fis h in g m e a s u r e 
WASHINGTON (AP) - Congress swiftly adopted and sent to President 
Carter on Tuesday a series of agreements that w ill allow Japan, 
Spain, South Korea and eight Western 
European nations to resume commer­ cial lisping in U.S. territorial waters. 
F ishing by ships of those nations was halted at m idnight Monday as the 
United States’ new 2oo-mile offshore limit went into effect. The craft were ordered to hoist and stow their fishing gear or face possible seizure by the 
C S. Coast Guard. 
Despite claims by opponents that the pact involving Japan gives that nation preferential treatment and contains a dangerous loophole, the House voted 
377 to 18 to approve the Governing In­ ternational Fishing Agreements 
(GIFA) that permit foreign nations to apply for fishing rights in U.S. waters. 
It suspended a 6o-day waiting period normally required for Congress to study such proposals. 
The measure then was adopted by the Senate on a voice vote, after Sen. 
Claiborne Pell. D-R.l., called for quick action to assure that American allies. as well as “ those who are not always our best friends.” can resume fishing.

New tax system is eyed by CCA 

The City-County Appraisal Office is developing a new staff unit to analyze property Guiles prices used in.tax as­ sessments. 
The new unit was described Tuesday to the four CCA board members by 
CCA Dir. Arthur de la Garza. 
To date. CCA has used only the original cost of properties to establish tax appraisal values locally, de la 
Garza pointed out. 
His move to beef up capability for analyzing sales data comes as a direct response to criticism leveled by city lax officials in a special report to City 
Council. 
De la Garza also told the board he plans to review prospects for improved aerial mapping as a property identifi­ cation tool and will seek comments from other agencies interested in up­ dating local county maps. 
F'or Tuesday’s meeting. City Coun­ cilmen Phil Pyndu and Boh Billa. 
County Judge Blair Reeves and Com. 
Jeff W e n tw o rth were present. 
Wentworth sat in for Com. Albert 
Bustamante. 
De la Garza w-as also directed to review a taxing procedures study by 

 the Research and Planning Council of 
San Antonio Spokesmen for the coun­ cil briefed CCA on the report first. 
Some of the findings in that study should be applied to existing proce­ dures, according to County Judge Blair 
Reeves. 

He and F’yndus. CCA board chair­ man. agret*d some changes should be made in assessing procedures to re­ duce the gap between appraisals and actual market price of properties 
The study looks only at about 3.DOO residential properties throughout Bex­ ar County. It does not examine any commercial property. 
Among its findings are figures showing that older homes are ap­ praised at lower rates than newer homes and that taxing bodies fre­ quently assess the same piece of pro­ perty at different values. 
“ The trends show us something, lf we don’t respond we would be negli­ gent. Let’s use this report.” Pyndus declared 
De la Garza is to return to the board in two weeks with a review ot the appraisal report. 
Pre-schooler plan draws demonstration 

By LIZ SWEET 
A proposal to relocate 323 pre-school children sparked a protest demonstra­ tion by Edgewood School District resi­ dents Tuesday. 
The proposal comes under a policy the trustees are considering which would remove the 4-year-olds from the 
Jose Angel Cardenas Early Childhood 
Center to allow it to be used for handi­ capped students. 
The center presently is used by both groups. 
The proposed relocation is in re­ sponse to a federal mandate requiring all school districts to provide education for handicapped children by 198(1. 
M innie Aleman, leader of the demonstration, said about 12o com­ munity members carried signs in peaceful protest to express their con­ cern before the issue comes up for a vote. 

Mrs. Aleman said a district com­ mittee. of which she was a member, conducted a feasibility study which concluded there were many ways to apply for enough funding to cover the needs of handicapped children. 
"I turned in my report which was censored by the school district board because of what I said There is no reason to take away the education of these 4 year olds to provide education for others,” Mrs. Aleman said 

The district must meet federal re­ quirements, however, even if sacri­ fices have to be made. Trustee Jaime 
Martinez said. 
The pre-school program — the only one of its kind in the city — is not a state-mandated program, he noted. 

Mrs Aleman said the district has made no provisions for the relocation of the pre-schoolers.

F'irst Ladv

Carter, offered no debate during the hour-and-a- half the issue was on the floor.

F C C ruling overturned 
WASHINGTON - The 
U.S. Court of Appeals ruled Tuesday thai the same company cannot own a newspaper and a telex IMW or radio station in the same city unless the joint operation is in the public interest.

SA N A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Wednesday March 2 1977 

Your 

Allergies shots need planning 

Dear Dr. Thosteson : My child has suffered from allergy to spring pollens, but we've never had him desensitized. With the coming of spring soon we would like to let him have one carefree year. When should we start tin* shots.’ Who would give them'.’ 
Are they effective? — Mrs. T K 
Kirst of all. it depends on inst what pollens you are speaking of. That has to be determined first of all. and if it hasn t yet been done, you may have a lengthy period before you can start the child on any shots 
Where you live may also have much to do with it. lf tree pollen causes his problem, you have to consider that these pollinate earlier in the southern K S. than in the northern section. 
The same seasonal var­ iances apply to other culprits such as fall pol­ len from weeds and grasses. 
According to Km ile 
Somekh, M .K ., in h is book, "Allergy and Your 
Child,” tin* most effec­ tive desensitization is perennial, that is, where injections are given throughout the year 
T h is is the type favored by most allergists. 
At the beginning, says Dr. Somekh. the child receives one injection weekly, and once the* maxi­ mum tolerated dose is reached (after four or five months) the frequency of shots is slowly reduced to one per month. 
Dr. Somekh recommends injections to be given for three or four consecutive years. When the child is sy m p to m - fre e for two years, treatment may be stopped,. other desensitization methods involve injections during the actual pollen season and the pro-seasonal method, where tin* shots begin three months before tin* approaching pollen season. Some physicians may prefer those* methods. 
I suggest you see an allergist, who w ill be* familiar with local pollen seasons. Desensitization, properly administered, his highly effective* and for the* ser­ iously allergic child most worthwhile 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Someone has told me thilt anyone who has a liver condition should never e*at liver Is there any truth iii this? — Mrs. HAI. 
Only if the* blood cholesterol is elevated. Liver is h ig h iii cholesterol. I presume that by the term 
"liver condition” you mean hepatitis or cirrhosis.

 and 25 cents.

The Aces 
On Bridge 

Bl IR V G .CORN IR. 

“ Nothing is easier to avoid than publicity 
If one ge­ nuinely doesn t want it. one doesn’t get ii ” --C F Snow 
The same does not always hold true for bridge cham­ pions Some would have only their good plays noticed and their bad ones forgotten. To­ day’s hand is a good example. 
The play might be an embar­ rassment to both sides, but fortunately, it was played in the 1976 Olympics bv some who can take the bad with the good. 
The contract and bidding were the same in both rooms and with the Swiss playing the no trump game. Michel 
Lebel of Paris led the king of hearts This proved no prob­ lem since dummy hat! two stoppers and declarer wrap­ ped up ten tricks with ease via a winning club and dia­ mond finesse 
W h e n th e h a n d w a s replayed. Pietro Bernascom of Switzerland led a cunning h e a rt ten. 
Je a n - M ic h e l 
Boulenger of P a ris was declarer and he played low from dummy thinking that 
East had one of the high honors 
West wasn’t about to let go of a good thing and he con­ tinued with the nine. ducked once again in dummy Next 
West produced the heart seven and dummy's ace was

Tedd Ross, Stanley Clay, Saundra Sharp, Art Evans and Gene Bell star. (Ch. 5) 

 played. East exposing West’s ruse by discarding a spade 
(declarer discarded a spade and two diamonds on the three heart leads! 
Declarer recovered 'with 
East's help* when he played the ace of clubs and let the nine of clubs ride for a suc­ cessful finesse 
The club finesse was repeated and declarer took nine tricks with a sigh of relief (imagine los­ ing to a possible West's club oueen to suffer the agony of discarding on the king and queen of hearts)

By DAN LEW IS 

" M y grandparents didn t believe I had made it until they saw me on the Mike Douglas show,” 
Barry Manilow joked. 
“ But. for my mother. I didn t make it until she saw me in the M acy’s 
Thanksgiving's Day par­ ade. 
” 1 have gold albums, have been on Johnny 
( arson’s show. Mort 
Griffin and Douglas. But as far as Mom was con­ cerned. I didn t become a star until she saw nu* in the parade.” 
H e’s tall, lean, his blond hair is a s.rag cut. lie s been an arranger, producer and conductor for Bette M id ler, and many insist her career didn t begin to zoom until 
B a rry Manilow showed up at the Continental 
Baths to play piano for her act. 
He has written some of the more memorable hits 
— commercials, that is. lh* has composed and re­ corded such hit songs as 
“ Mandy,” ” 1 Write the 
Songs,” and gold albums 
"B a rry Manilow I” and 
“ Barry Manilow IL ” On 
Broadway, he performed in concert at the Kris for two sold-out weeks. 
Inevitably, there is to be a television special. 
“ The B a rry Manilow 
Special" will be aired on 
ABC, Wednesday night 
“ I hope not many will be disappointed when they tune in that night and find Barry Manilow instead of ‘Charley’s An­ gels.'” Barry observed, noting his special will be preempting the biggest new hit of the season. 
Who would com plain about the chance to see 
Barry Manilow instead of 
Earrah Kaw celt-Ma jots •’ 
Barry has come a long way m television from tilt* days he worked as a mail-room messenger at 
C BS. when one of his daily stops was at the of­ fice of one Fred Silver­ man. at the network de­ partment. 
Now Barry is doing a special for that same 
Fred Silverm an , cu r­ rently president of ABC 
Entertainment. 
“ When I went to Fred’s office at ABC to discuss the special, the first thing he said to me was, 
‘W h ere’s my m a il?’” 
Manilow recalled. 
B a rry speht three months preparing his TV debut. It was taped in Los 
Angeles and New York. 
P a rt of the New York shooting was on location in Times Squar e and also 
Third Avenue to his mu­ sic. “ New York City 
Rhythm." 
It s on the screen for three minutes. Barry ex­ plained. It took 21 hours to shoot. 
“ lf you like me. the show is fabulous," Mani- lovv declared. “ If you don t — don’t watch the show." • 
Manilow thinks his songs have wide appeal, from young to an adult- center. Ile concents him­ self with commercial ap­ peal and feels the show has it including a medley of his hit commercials. 
“ Telev ision is the rat­ ings game. You can win 
Kmmys and not get rat­ ings. I watched Arthur 
Ruhcnstiein on Pu b lic

PBS with money. I want to keep it alive," Mani­ low revealed. 

His songs 
Manilow m aintained, are vers personal. The special is another m irror of him ­ self. although Manilow prefers not to call it a TY special, hut rather a movie. 

“ It s a special spe­ cial.” he said, “ like an old Playhouse 9(1. It is not a variety show. No shiny linoleum on the floor or lav ish costumes." 

His only guest will he 
Penny Marshall of " L a ­ verne and Shirley." 

Named the top male singles vocalist of I DTH by two music trade publica­ tions. Manilow dedicates the show to his late grandfather, who was his earliest m usical in ­ fluence. going back to his boyhood days in Brook­ lyn's W illiamsburg sec­ tion. 

 lbs musical talents first surfaced as a se­ ven-year-old aecordian- lst. He studied advertis­ ing at City College of New 
York for a year. Then he switched to the New York 
College of Music, work­ ing his way through school as that mail-room messenger at CBS.

Kimbrough quits race, supports Steen 

By JAMBS MCCRORY 
The first candidate to announce for the City 
Council from District IO 
Tuesday withdrew in fa­ vor of another candidate from the same district. 
John Kimbrough, who resigned as treasurer of the Bexar County Repub­ lican party to make the race, announced he is withdrawing to support 
Jo h n 
Ste e n , f o r m e r chairman of the defunct 
Good 
G o v e r n m e n t 
League. 
After four y e a r s of 
“ le a d e r l e s s g o v e r n ­ m e n t ” in San Antonio and interference by the council in affairs right­ fully belonging to the city m a n a g e r , 
K im b r o u g h said he had hoped Steen would run for mayor. 
After Steens election this year and two years of service on the council, 
Kimbrough said, a m a ­ jority of San Antonians will agree in the P»7‘i elections Steen should be mayor. 
San Martin 
Even a s K im b ro u g h w a s w i th d r a w i n g as a ca n d id a te , other c a n d i­ dates were pressing their suit with voters. 
Dr. Jose San Martin, a form er m a y o r pro tem who is r u n n i n g for mayor, won the support of a group of black sup­ porters. San Martin a d ­ dressed the group. East 
Side Voters Com m ittee for Dr. San M artin for 
M ayor, at 
2326 
E. 
Commerce St. 
San M artin also met with the Baptist M inis­ ters Union. 
The John Monfrey for 
M ay o r C o m m itte e a n ­ nounced a country and w e ste rn show for Mon­ frey in his bid for the mayor's post at 7 p.m. 
M arch 
9 in 
Villita 
Assembly Hall 
Monfrey addressed the 
Young Democrats at San 
Antonio College Tuesday. 
Leadership lack 

Monfrey told the Young 
Democrats and students 
San Antonio “ has e v e r­ ything going for it except its standard of living.'* 
The major reason for 
Uu* lack of development in the city. Monfrey ob­ served, is the lack of the right kind of leadership. 
The mayoral candidate suggested San Antonio major hanking and busi­ ness institutions should 
5 m ore run for council 

Five more hats were tossed into the 
City 
Council race Tuesday as deadline for tiling a p ­ proaches. bringing the total to date to 72. 
Filing ends at 4:3U p.m. 
Wednesday.

33. a m a c h i n e shop owner, of 461o Wyeliff 
Drive, filed as a candi­ date for mayor.

E. Petaluma Blvd., a re­ tired civil se rv ic e worker, for District 3.

 set up th e ir own economic developm ent foundation to attract new industry. 
Monfrey also suggest­ ed a task force be set up to solicit com panies in the north victimized by bad weather. 
Other candidates were making their presences known and their voices heard Tuesday. 

Jim Dement, a candi­ date for the council from 
District 9. warned unless revenue sh a rin g funds a re m a d e a v ailab le to expand and continue the city's Emergency Medi­ cal Service, “ we could lose this valuable and vi­ tal service." 
In rem arks to the Re­ publican B usiness Wo­ men’s Club, Dement not­ 

 ed each citizen of the city pays $4o a year in taxes for police protection and 
$33 per person per year for fire protection but only $3.33 a y ear for emergency medical se r­ vices. 
Action urged 
“ Something has to bi* done to insure the con­ tinuance of EMS s e r ­ 

 vices.” Dement asserted. 
District 6 council can­ d id ate 
J o s e 
Est a l a , sp e a k in g at a public hearing on disbursement of $7.6 million in federal revenue sharing funds, said a portion should be used to bring city water to needy a re a s such as 
Hillside Acres and Mobil 
Homes Heights. Lack of adequate water pressure. 

E sta la said, often p r e ­ vents use of w a sh in g machines and bathroom facilities. He said neither 
Hillside nor 
Mobile 
Homes bas fire hydrants, and as a result they have no fire protection and their insurance rates are higher than areas with such protection. 
On the District 8 front, 
W innie V e tte r, s a y in g 

 she has spent a grand to­ tal of $9.24 cents on her campaign for the council so far, an n o u n c e d she will not accept campaign c o n trib u tio n s. 
She doesn’t think such con­ tributions arc necessary to win. 
Park proposed 
Mrs. Vetter suggested land over the E d w a rd s 

 a q u ifer r e c h a r g e zone could be developed into a city p a rk , with p la y ­ ground equipment, a ball p ark , bike tr a ils, a skateboard track, picnic tables and restrooms. 
Two incumbent coun­ cilm en T u e sd a y also were preparing to shift th e ir c a m p a i g n s into high.

W. Woodlawn Ave.

June M endoza gets 4o years 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesday March 2 1977 
H 

.ll NE MENDOZA 
,. stiff sentence 

F o rm er Corpus C hristi h a lf­ way house operator June Bunch 
Mendoza m ay spend 4o years as an inm ate in federal prison for sellin g 2o pounds of heroin to a federal drug agent. 
Chief U.S. Hist. Judge Adrian A 
Spears handed down the stiff sentence 
Munday and said he agreed totally with the jury’s verdict in the case. 
Mrs. Mendoza's husband, Arturo 
Keyes Mendoza, was sentenced to 35 years in federal prison and his brother, 

Oscar Keyes Mendoza, was sentenced to 43 years behind bars. 
All three received special parole terms of 3D years which will begin after they have served the initial sen­ tence. 
They were all convicted of conspir­ acy in the case. which included four transactions between Mrs. Mendoza and a Drug Enforcement Administra­ tion undercover agent. 
Mrs. Mendoza was also convicted on four counts of possession of heroin with intent to distribute. 

Oscar Mendoza was found guilty on three possession counts and Arturo w as conv icted on two of the possession charges. 
T h roughout the trial and d u r in g sentencing proceedings, the Mendozas maintained they participated in the co n sp ira c y because an in fo rm a n t working with DEA agents threatened their children. 
But Judge Spears said, “ I have no difficulty agreeing with the jury ver­ dict 1ooo per cent. 
“ I don't think these people were 

 threatened.” the judge said. “ This was a p r e m e d i t a te d , cold, c a l c u l a t i n g crime.” 
Both Prado and Austin attorney Hu­ bert Looney, who represented Mrs 
Mendoza and O scar Mendoza, said they would appeal the conviction to the 
Sib U S. Circuit Court of Appeals. 

At the time of her arrest, Mrs. Jeu* doza owned the Knotty Pines C o m ­ munity T reatm en t Center in Corpus 
Christi, a halfway house for soon-to-be paroled convicts.

 nursing red tape urged 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 

FO KT WORTH - The state can improve nurs­ ing home efficiency by c utting a d m in i s t r a t i v e red tape while tightening regulatory methods. 
That is the heart of r e c o m m e n d a t io n s p r e ­ pared Tuesday by the s tate 
Medicaid task force's subeommittte on n ursing homes r e c o m ­ mendations, according lo 
City Councilman Henry 
Cisneros, subcommittee chairman. 
The six committees of the 47-member task force arc meeting here Tues­ day and Wednesday to hear testimony and pre­ pare initial re co m m en ­ dations to the state wel­ fare bourd. 
“ We must find a means to reduce unreasonable a d m in is tr a te e burdens on nursing home owners while developing a more valid inspection s y s ­ tem.” Cisneros said. 
“ The p e n d u lu m of red-tape and regulatory malfunction is producing cost inefficiencies in the program. 
“ What is needed is a swing hack toward more administrative autonomy to providers coupled with a more meaningful in­ spection s y s t e m , ” he said. 
Inspection 
( isn ero s a d d e d th e state inspection of homes must be improved. “ We need to m a k e s u r e in ­ spectors inspect the qua­ lity of patient can*, not lust medical records and files. 
“ We hope lo make the sy ste m m o re r a tio n a l, and we believe this dual purpose will reduce cost inefficien cies and e n ­ hance the q u a lity of care.”

M a n a g in g Editor 
State’s big surplus m ay go in a hurry 

They’re trying to slice the big pie in Austin these days. 
W hile top le a d e r s h ip was battling their own budget views in the State Capitol, Comptrol­ ler Bob Bullock added up pro­ posed totals on spending goals. lie projected slightly more than 
$2 billion over current spending levels — assuming good econo­ m ic co n d itio n s hold th ro u g h next biennium. 
And he jolted the Legislature and the T e x a s public with a forecast of a deficit of $3o4 mil­ lion, based on pending proposals in the L e g i s la tu r e — and e x ­ cluding teacher pay raise, pro­ perty tax changes, sales tax re­ duction and w hat he called 
“ hundreds of other minor pro­ posals.” 
The m essage which Bullock never spelled out is that work needs to be done between com ­ peting in te re s ts for a budget balance before — not after — major appropriations are signed into law. 
The hard fight is over dedi­ cated highway funds. 
If the g o v e r n o r ’s goal for road funds is accepted, schools will get less th a n th e ir supporters anticipate. 
Couple those items with tax re d u c tio n s s u re to c o m e and th e re is a d efic it, w hich the 
Constitution disallows, or a tax 

 has bill, which the g o v e rn o r promised to veto. 
There is room for construc­ tive c o m p ro m is e and t h e r e 's even room within revenue esti­ mates to hold back something in the treasury. We don't expect the Legislature to leave anyth­ ing there, and we certainly don't expect it to pass a new tax bill. 
One th in g the L e g is la tu re should do is review the State 
Auditor’s 1973 report on money m anagem ent. That study indi­ cates where legislation is need­ ed to ach iev e and keep good money management. When the study was done, T exas was earning less than one per cent on deposits of funds. That inter­ est earning has been increased to seven per cent. 
Bullock said the State Depo­ sitory Board has dropped inter­ est paid on state money to six per cent. 
The d e p o s ito ry b o a rd has c o m p le te d is c re tio n on that matter. The auditor's proposal is to set limits on discretion. 
The one point drop in interest rates will cost the state $21.5 million, according to Bullock. It may be time to consider seeking bids for state depository. 
We know it is time for state leaders to work toward a spend­ ing total before freezing specific appropriations into law. 

School im provem ent delayed by lack o f voter confidence 

P u b lic con fid e n ce p a s s e s bond issues. 
The more complex the issue, the least likely it is to pass. And when — as in the case of last 
Saturday’s school bond issue for the big San Antonio district — taxes go up with the bond issue, it takes a compelling case to win approval. 
Confidence in the proposers of the proposals was insuffi­ cient. 
Thus, the trustees’ job is to start now to build confidence of the public. A pathy won the election and the tru ste es lost. 
The han d fu l of v o te rs who turned out showed either indif­ ference or confusion on the part of those who didn't. Opposition to the bonds — to the trustees, really — surfaced with surpris­ ing intensity. The fight was, in a 
Amin still due a I . N. visi* 

The good news from Uganda is that Idi Amin felt the pressure of his neighbors as well as pub­ lic opinion e l s e w h e r e and changed his mind about w h at­ ever it was he thought he was thinking about last week. 
Americans were free to leave the country and some were do­ ing that. 
Meantime, the U. N. Human 
Hights Commission should be persuaded to send a delegation 

 way, a re-run last year's trustee election. 
New trustees com prom ised themselves at the outset with an awkward attempt to split a bid to supply the district with milk without a supportable reason. 
F ro m th a t point, su sp ic io n s never subsided. 
Need for renovation of old buildings and co nstruction of new ones re m a in s . The bond proposal was one of the most detailed we ever read. N eigh­ borhood cooperation in p re p a r­ ing the list of things to do with bond money was extensive. 
Trustees should take the re­ buff in stride and work out a new approach to their problem, because the district does need to offer good facilities along with good teachers for a quality job of educational opportunity.

. However, if ah was a serpent, ah might be tempted to act the same way!'

Mould steal your guns 

Sir: If I were a burglar, here’s w hat I would be thinking about people like that Hill Country couple who arm ed themselves to the teeth in o rd er to curtail my business: 
So va got some guns, huh? Gutta- sight! I really dig people like you because you're good for business. My fence tells me that handguns and rifles are the easiest stolen goods to move. 
Look, Wyatt E arp, do you actually think I'm crazy enough to break into your place when you are at hom e? 
Even though I'm a low-life junkie and am in a narcotic haze most of the tim e 
I still have better sense than that! 
What are you going to do, stay in your house 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 12 m onths a year? You will diligently go to work every m orning and eventually the wife will have to leave the house to do h er grocery shopping, etc. 
T hat's when I'll ransack your place, when the coast is clear. And the first things Ell g ra b will be your high- quality arm am ent. Too bad you didn't think of something else, like a silent ala rm or a pair of huge Doberman 
Pinschers. 
Yeah. I really dig people who think th a t they can protect th e ir vacant hollies with the weapons I have in my b urglar's bag.

 response to Mr. Notzon's allegation that the proposal m ight be d iscrim in ­ atory.

It’s a most ingenious paradox 

BOSTON — Federal law es­ tablishes a policy objective for the country; to reduce air pol­ lution, for instance, or hire more women and minorities. 
In trying to enforce the policy, the governm ent should have an e a sie r tim e p e rsu a d in g its own a g e n c ie s than private industries. 
Right? 
Wrong, say Ja m es Q Wilson, pro­ fessor of government at H arvard, and 
Patricia Rachal, a g rad u ate student there. 
W riting in the w inter issue of the quarterly The Public Interest, they argue convincingly that it is usuuilv hard er for governm ent to change the attitu d es of public agencies than ot private institutions 
One example 

One exam ple they give is the Labor 
Department O ffice of F e d e ra l Con­ tractu Com pliance, which is suppose! to m ake federal agencies see to it (fiat contractors doing business with them 

 have p rogram s to hire m inority e m ­ ployes and women 
OFCC is widely considered to have little or no im pact on the other go­ vernm ent departm ents. 
T he Civil R ights Com m ission has said it is such a failure that it should 

Im* abolished. 
O r c o m p a re the pollution p e rfo r­ m ance of the Tennessee Valley Auth­ ority w ith that of private u tilitie s subject to federal environm ental re ­ gulations. 
T h e a u th o rs c o n c lu d e th at TVA generating plants foul the air m ore than many private plants. 
Why so slow 
Why stiouid governm ent agencies lie slow to c a r r y out g o v e r n m e n t policy? 
Wilson and Miss R adial explore the p ara d o x aud su g g e st a n u m b e r ut reasons having to do with the forces that operate on the managerial m ind, such as law and money and b u reau ­ cracy, lf a private institution fails to carry out a law or r e g u la tio n , th e 

 g o v ern m e n t m ay go to co u rt. The 
E n v iro n m en tal P rotection Agency, for exam ple, is actively engaged in litigation to m ak e industry reduce pollution, 

Financial incentives 
But one governm ent agency cannot usually sue another It will Im* a long wait until the DECC sues, say, the 
Defense D epartm ent for failing to see that its contractors increase minority hirin g . It would be a r e m a rk a b le event if the EPA tried to bring the* 
T e n n e s s e e V alley A u th o rity into court 

F inancial incentives m ay also be relevant. 

If electric utilities have to install s c ru b b e rs in th e ir sm o k e s ta c k s to rem ove su lfu r com p o u n d s, they or­ dinarily can pass on the cost. 
In d eed , a pollution tax has been suggested, so that com panies reduc­ ing pollution would pay less in taxes. 
But the TVA bus a different p u r­ pose in life: to produce electricity as c h e a p ly a s p o s s ib le , us a “ y a r d ­ stick,” It is not subject to the sam e rate or tax in cen tiv es in installing anti-pollution (levices. 
Then there are b u rea u cra tic r e a ­ lities. lf a low-ranking civil servant iii tin 
DECC tr ie s to force c h a n g e on til* 
D efense D epartm ent, he is not likely to get m uch of a hearing. 
Have to listen 
After all. he cannot cut tile d e p a rt­ m en t’s budget or sue it or penalize it 

 iii any other effective way — unless tie can get the White House in te rest­ ed. and that it unlikely. 
But private institutions have to lis­ ten, like it ar not, when the sam e civil servant s|M*aks lo them 

He may have the power to cut oft the contract, or involve them in liti­ gation. He is not just one bureaucrat m aneuvering against another. 

T h e P u b lic I n te r e s t a r tic le is a start ut what ought to be a fresh way of looking at the old arg u m e n t about public and private enterprise. 

Its paradoxical-sounding argum ent should provoke political thinkers in boti, th e U n ite d S ta te s an d th o se 
W estern co u n tries with m ore socia­ lized economies, such as Britain and 
F rance 
Iii this country, the problem of in­ efficient and u n re sp o n siv e g o v e rn ­ m ent was a m ain th em e of Jim m y 
C arter’s cam paign. 

He is now testing Ins answer: reo r­ ganization of the federal governm ent. 
T h ere plainly is a need for r e o r ­ ganization; in an encrusted system , change itself is a good thing. 

But this analysis rem in d s us that there are deeper difficulties in m a k ­ ing the bureaucracy respond to p ub­ lic i»ol icy. 

 rapist 
Dallas celebrity 

DALLAS — Virtually every conversation in Dallas these days soon gels around to the new celebrity. 
No. peo p le a r e not ta lk in g a b o u t their neighborhood Ford dealer or the new p hilosopher at S outhern M etho­ dist. 
They are talking about the “ friendly rapist.” 
You see. people say over and over. 
Guy W illiam M arble J r. never really 
“ h u rt” anybody. 
In th e t h r e e y e a r s t h a t th is sa n d y -h a ire d , m u sta c h io ed P o rsch e- set executive terrorized the sw inging singles area, he usually told the wo­ m an. “ I'm just your friendly b u rg la r." 
Nom de plum'* 
T h at se e m s to be how his nom de plum e (de g u erre?) got started. 
Today, the police blam e the m edia aud the m edia blam e the police, but the fact is, the nam e has stuck. 
One wom an w as “ dow nright m ad " when she found that her rapist was not old “ F riendly." 
( apt. Donald II. Milliken, the bright young Dallas police officer who over­ saw the successful cam paign against 
M arble, doesn't like the n icknam e but he was overruled by society’s apparent need to personalize even King Kong. 
“ He’s been m ade into som ething of a legend around here — and a cele b ri­ ty,’’ Milliken says. 
“ It's the good, old Robin-Hood-rapist idea. People in the co m m u n ity have tended to go along with it because lie w asn't raping little old ladies and be­ cause lie did n ’t hurt anybody. 
‘Feeds his ego' 
“ I didn t like his getting glam orized because it feeds his ego. Once I did a 
TV show on him because I was really try in g to get the girls to close their windows. Instead, I just got an im pos­ tor on F rien d ly ” 
Yes, an im postor. 
There is another one running loose in 
Dallas who m im ics “ F rie n d ly ’s ” style. 
In addition, the police here have re ­ ceived calls from police in other parts of Texas, in O klahom a and in Florida. 
Florida has a "g e n tle ra p ist” and all have sim ilar, unsolved crim es. 
Y es, it's a s tr a n g e c a s e , p e rh a p s even a classic case — and a case that perfectly fits the very special lifestyle of the singles areas. 
Not common 
M arble was no com m on stree t ru n ­ ner. He was the well-paid vice p re si­ dent of an advertising subsidiary. Ile m ust have had an understanding wife, because he is m a rrie d , with a child 
A pparently, he got out at all hours by p re te n d in g to be jo gging — then lie would clim b into single w om en's room s through the windows and rape them. 
In his areas, the girls often left their windows open so their boyfriends could use som e ingenuity in com ing in. None of it struck anybody as very strange. 
“ You could set off d ynam ite in those places ut high noon and people would only think you were having a p a rty .” says Milliken with dry hum or. 
But, “ friendly?" 
Interpretation 
Well, I suppose that depends upon your in te rp retatio n of our society to­ day. 
Ile did use a knife and often th re a ­ tened to kill the women. 
He cut phone cords. 
Ile w a s a d m i t t e d to 43 r a p e s , is ch a rg ed with th re e and shocked the police by ad m ittin g to 12 that hadn t even been reported. 
Ile is the Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde ot the Texas ranges. But he just as well co u ld h a v e b e e n th e S lu g of th e 
G e o rg ia S w a m p s or th e Dog of the 
P rairies. 
He is all-Am erican. 
After all. in advertising today it is now com m onplace (and ap parently a splendid selling technique) to picture women being tortured or m urdered. 
New era in rape? 
Isn’t it possible that, as a reaction against w om en’s growing freedom and power, we have entered a kind of new era in rape? 
Isn't it possible that we are seeing played out a King of Rape T heater, in which we have gone all the way from the “ she had to want it” of our child­ hoods to a new “ if sh e’s liberated, she has to like it — unless she s curved up. of co u rse” ? 
Of course, m any people don’t like it. and the Dallas papers w ere besieged by phone calls from angry women, ob­ viously with unfriendly instinct toward 
Marble. 
Many of the raped women, tra u m a ­ tized, have moved away. 
But ironically, it is the police, who once looked al r a p e w ith less th an anger, who now take the whole thing most seriously. 
Tight case 
The police think they have a tight ease against him . but m any people are angrily convinced he’ll Im* oui in three years. 
As for M arble, like Howard Hunt and

N ew m an) c r im in a ls of our in d iscri minuting tim e, he is talking aireudv about w riting a book. 
Now this is good, because m aybe hi can tell us how lie didn’t “ hurt” any body. 
Dozens of women raped. 
And nobody hurt.
