Space towns could spread into universe 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesdov Morch 2 I 977 
H 
Po9e 15:A 

Bv ISAAC ASIMOV 
Suppose we were to develop a ll the uses of space that I have spoken of in previous sections. 
Suppose we hue] space power sta­ tions. space factories, space hospitals, space laboratories — some iii orbit about the earth aud some on the sur­ face. or just under the surface, of the moon. 
It would be very uneconomical to have people constantly commuting between earth and the various space structures. it would make much more sense to establish bases where people could live for indefinite periods — all their lives. if they wished — visiting earth rarely or never. 
Space settlements 
Such space settlements could be on the moon. a large world which would 
.give people the feeling of elbow room they are accustomed to us well as all the oxygen they need — in combination with other substances that abound. 
It would also be a place where settlers would, iii any case, have to be. since the moon probably will be the source of the structural materials for all those objects in space. 
(The moon is short in the important volatile elements: hydrogen, carbon and nitrogen. These would have to be supplied, at least iii part, bv the earth.) 
The disadvantage of the moon is that its gravity is only one-sixth normal, and tins might raise difficulties for people who must spend part of their time on the moon and part on earth. 
Large structures 
I'lie alternative is to build large structures in space that can house anywhere from tens of thousands lo tens of millions of people. 
Such structures can be set spinning 

Commuting to the moon or nearby space settlements could become expensive and latiguing. lf you're gravity‘prone, so the adventurous young earthman and his family may just move up yonder for good. 

In this last of a four-part series, noted science fiction author Dr. 
Isaac Asimov foresees a time when more people may be living iii space than on earth. 

Nor does he think we should stop short of the edge of our own planetary system. 

Calling space “ an open door to the universe," hr urges us to walk through it. 

 at rates of two times a minute or less. depending un their size: this would create a centrifugal effect that would push people and objects against the inner surface aud give the illusion and force of gravity. 
The shape of such settlements might be cylinders or spheres or doughnuts. 
Sense of gravity 
Iii such space settlem ents, the centrifugal effect would give the feeling of normal gravity, though there would always he places in the settle­ ment where the gravity would be lower than normal by different degrees — right down to zero. iii fact — so that low-gravity or zero-gravity work could be done. 
The space settlements could be built out of moon materials (there would always have to be the equivalent of a mining colony on the moon) and the smelting would lie done iii space. 
The settlements could be engineered toward creating the inner surface de­ sired — farm lands, suburban gardens, streams, even mountains. 

It many settlements were built (one of tin* main tasks of the settlers would be to build additional settlements, sn that neither the raw materials nor the labor force would be a great drain on earth itself), eventually there could be wide varieties of inner appearance. 
•beliefs, languages, ways of life — all ut which would add richness to human culture over-all. 
New generation 4 
The space settlers would very likely supply the new generation of people to man the various structures iii space and the mining colony on the moon. 
Knelt settlement would have a solar energy station for its own use; the settlers would eventually take over the task of repairing and maintaining the stations serving earth. 
Kventijally, with enough space settlements, it could happen that the human population — which soon must be stabilized in numbers on carib if civ ilizatiou is to s h i v iv e — may enter a new era of expansion. 
The time could come when there might be more people til space than on earth. 
Wide of mark 
We see. then, that people who view the establishment of space settlements as un economic drain oil the earth are wide of the mark 
The truth is, we are likely to profit so highly from the work of space settlers thai we ll be hard put to return a favor commensurate with tile value of their labors in our belial! 

Perhaps tile space settlers most use!ut function would be as explorers. 

Earthmen have reached the moon. but that is a simple trip taking only three days. 

To reach the next logical target. 
Mars, would lake months; anything beyond Mars might take years. 

SPACE FAM ILIES could g r o w a s e x p lo ra tio n of sp ace g o e s b e y o n d our o w n so la r sy ste m to the distant stars. 

For astronauts t" journey that long iii crumped ships, so unlike what they arc used to on carib would be very difficult. 
Psychologically. it might prove im­ possible, 
Difference 

It would !»• different for the space settlers. 
Iii the first place, they would regard space flight not as something strange but as the ordinary condition of life. 

They, or their parents, will have reached the settlement by spaceflight, and they will have to use spaceflight to do the work of m ining the moon, building new settlements, servicing energy stations and manning the var­ ious laboratories, hospitals and fac­ tories iii space 

Second, the spaceship itself will be much more homelike to them than to earthmen. 

Here on earth, we live on the outside of a world and are used to vastness. 

Iii a settlement, people will have to livi* on the inside of a world and be used to a limited volume and to the careful recycling of all resources 

A spaceship would not he very dif- 
ENERGY AGENCY OUTLINE 

 a number of programs from other agencies, including: 
• From the Interior Department, the regional electric power m arketing programs; the Bureau of Mines fuel data program anil coal technology re­ search; a major share of authority over the leasing of federal energy re ­ sources; aud control over the rate of exploration of Naval Petroleum He- serve Number Four iii Alaska, due for transfer from the Navy to the Interior 
Department on duly I under curlier legislation. 
The four power-marketing agencies are Bonneville. Alaska. Southwest and 
Southeast Power administrations. 
• From the Department of Housing and I'rbun Development, the program of heating and cooling standards for buildings. 
• From the Commerce Department, the program for voluntary industrial energy conserv at ion. 
• From the D efense Department, jurisdiction over three N aval P e ­ troleum Reserves iii California and 
Wyoming, and three Naval oil shale reserves iii Colorado and I tall 
• From the Securities and exchange 
I omiiiission. authority to regulate mergers among electric utilities. 
• And from the Interstate ( 'nm merci* 
Commission, authority to regulate oil pipelines and anticipated “ slurry " pipelines lo transport coal mixed with water. 
The plan includes an unusual divi­ sion of authority between two depart­ ments over the management of federal lauds containing oil, gas, c ital or other energy resources, now held by the In­ terior Department alone. 
Under Carter's proposal, the Interior 
Department would continue to issue te ases for energy development on these tcderul lands, would write “ general regulations," aud would enforce lease prov isioiis 
But the basic policies governing leasing a lid energy production would be set by the new Department til en­ ergy. which would establish the 
“ economic terms and conditions of 

 leases" including bidding a rra n ­ gements and mandatory production rates. lf the two departments disagree on federal land management, the P re ­ sident would have to settle their dis­ putes. the White House said. 
Sehlesinger told reporters this div i­ sion of responsibility over federal en­ ergy resources was one possible area for controversy in Congress. 
Another, he said. might be the proposal to bring the* Federal Power 
Commission — established by Con­ gress in Df.'l-l as an independent regulatory agency — into the new department, under the authority of a 
Cabinet secretary . 
Krueger’s unsure o f energy plan 

SPtC'Al IO tnt UWC SS 
WASHINGTON - U.S. Hep. 
Bob Krueger emerged from a 
White I louse meeting Tuesday with mixed feelings about Pre­ sident C arter’s new energy 
^organizational proposal. 
The President told Krueger and about W other I S. Senate and House members meeting ut the White House he is sending the proposal to the Senate and House for action. 
Those present al the meeting. 
Krueger said, were “ energy com ­ mittee people, basically." Krueger is a member of a House Energy Subcom­ mittee. 
Krueger said the President s propo­ sal takes a number of existing energy agencies and authorities “ and puts them under one umbrella 
Cnder the umbrella, he said. would be the Federal Energy Administration aud the Energy Research and Di ve- 

Sehlesinger said the intention was to give the secretary of energy the auth­ ority to establish general regulations over the natural gas and electricity industries which arc now established by the FFC. but to maintain a separate system of administrative law judges aud a hearings board to decide iu- div id na I cases. 
Sehlesinger said the reorganization proposal itself involves no changes of energy programs and policies now mandated by law. and would probably require review mainly by the Govern­ ment Operations Committees of the 
Senate and House of Representatives. 
R"jieoff announced that his Senate committee would hold hearings on

Sehlesinger was ut the meeting fI don’t care’ blues

It's called the old " I don't care; it s up to you'* or " I will ti you want-to" blues. Your partner never really knows titix\ Min stand on something. 
As I recall, it was suggested that a husband or wile spell it out using a scale of one to lo 
For example, it your husband says. “ Would you like tu go to a m ovie?" instead ul shrugging your shoulders and saying. "Makes no dif­ ference," you respond by saying ‘ I ’m five on attending a movie Actually. 
I'm eight on seeing the picture, but 
Pm two on spending tile money now

 from collecting more iii the total of their new salaries and their pensions* than their last salaries in the depart­ ments from which they retired. 
Any move by the new administration to cut military pay. allowances, fringe 
IxMiefits and pension costs would pro­ bably generate considerable contro­ versy m C ongress. 
Harold Brown, now secretary ut iff*. tense, bad said rn December the issue must be faced because personnel ex* 
Ih*nses now consume aa per cent of the defense budget and pension payments alone would reach SU billion rn fiscal year 1978, which begins Get I lf Carter should establish a com- mission on defense* personnel costs, it would be the latest of such study groups. A Defense Manpower < mn- mission created by Congress submit­ ted a lengthy report last year. 

Ford plan 

Also. two years ago President Ford recommended a pension reform plan. 
That plan would have extended a serviceman s period ut required ser­ vice before he could become eligible tor lull pension. 
To discourage those who stay on ac­ tive duty ‘JU years to get pension rights, the plan would have offered “ vested" pension rights to those who leave be­ fore JO years, to lie colic* table at age lia 
C o1 ig less has shown lift It* inclination to aet t*i reform the pension system or other m ilitary benefits, largely be­ cause of the military community’s op­ position. 
At present military personnel, who do not contribute ti* their pension sys­ tem. can retire ai att per cent of base pay after JO years ut serv ice aud al 7a 
IHT cent of base pay alter :M) years of serv let*. 
Floundered 

Many congressional observers be­ lieve past proposals for reform of mi­ litary benefits have floundered for lack of strong presidential sUpiHirt 
C arter's statements represented probably the strongest presidential commitment yet expressed to review­ ing aud changing the present system t arter drew applause from the au­ dience when lie said 
“ What ever might come iii the future vu* will assure the American people with and through you that our military strength aud our capability to delead freedom will tie second to none til all the world. 
And you eau depend on that 
Ile also remarked that military per­ sonnel "were not responsible for mis­ takes iii the past in unpopular wars. 

 fcrent from home — a luxury home at that. 
Tom orrow's space settler, in his controlled environs, will he far mon sheltered than millions of the earth s peoples who fight merely to survive on a daily basis. 
Unchanging 

Earth people are used to a high and unchanging gravitational pull. 
Settlers will be used to changes iii gravity intensity and surely will be familiar with zero grav ity. 
This contributes to making them feel at home in a spaceship which would In* only slowly rotating or. for that mat­ ter. on the surface of Mars. 
It may be. therefore, that th** true exploration of the solar sy stem, beyond the moon, will have to await the es­ tablishm ent of these space settle­ ments. 
W ill the new exploration be vv ort Ii w hilt;? 
Certainly. 
We have already sent two Viking probes to the surface ut Mars and we know that the soil there is surprisingly active. 
Th** kind of activity is what we might expect from life forms, but there is in* sign of the kind of molecules that we associate with life in th** soil. 
Peculiar changes 
Tin* activity may he from some pe­ culiar chemical changes we are not accustomed to on earth. 
Kuher way, the results are (mund to be of great importance to chemists, biologists, astronomers — and possibly to the general public as well if it ad­ vances our knowledge iii new and un­ expected directions. 

Since Viking hasn t given us hard and fast answers, we must send more sophisticated probes — that can per­ haps move about aud lest different ar­ eas. 
Best of all, we should send human beings — th** space settlers who could make the long trip with lower physical an*! psychological problem s than earthmen. 
Once (iii Mars, th** settlers could probe th** soil for ev idence of life with a versatility matched by no automatic 
(lev ice we now build. 
Failing to find life, tin* settlers ne­ vertheless could study the chemistry of the soil in detail 
They could maneuver freely to test different places. 
Atmosphere 

They might study the manner iii which the Martian atmosphere circu­ lates. 
A!ars has a planetary rotation almost exactly the period of our own. hut it lacks an ocean 
Its atmospheric circulation may be simpler, therefore; by learning the de­ tails. we can perhaps far better un­ derstand our own atmosphere. 
And if there were any hope of traveling Iteyond Mars — even to the distant stars — that would have to rest with the settlers. 
Besides being so potentially useful and profitable Im us, space is an open door to all th** rest of the universe. 
Our descendants would be thunder­ struck if loUi that we hesitated to use it. ll w**u 1*1 be as though our primitive ancestors had hesitated to use fire once it was discovered.

Stop smoking, Papa 

Dear Ann Landers: My lather-in-law is 77 years old. He lives in a home lei the ailed. Almost every weekend my husband and I pick him lip and bring him to our apartment to spend Friday and Saturday night 
Papa is very shaky and forget lid. Ile smokes constantly and I ve seen linn light up tin* filter end of a cigarette and put it in his mouth. 
He has burned holes in Ins pajamas, the bedsheets, quilts and the mattress. 
One night Iii* fell asleep on the couch and burned a huge hole iii t h e carpet where he had dropped a cigarette. 
My husband says we can't tell Papa not to smoke in our apartment because it might make him feel unwelcome. 
He also claims it wouldn’t do any good liecause the obi man gets mean as a rattlesnake when lie is crossed and does as he pleases 
We need advice. — Worried iii L A 
Dear 
I.. A.: 
Did you say 
A PA RT M EN T? For goodness sake wo­ man. don’t you realize you are jeopar­ dizing the lives ot every one of your 
(neighbors — as well as your own? 
Take away Papa s cigarettes and matches tin1 minute lit1 walks into your place and tell him “ M i M O R F 
SMOKING.*’ Or take turns slaying up all night and watching him every liv­ ing minute he is under vuur roof. 

Ann 
Landers 

Dear Ann: This letter is being written by three dudes (one junior, two sen­ iors! who go to a Long Island high school. Please answer the following questions \\ hy do so many chicks: 

I. F oo l around with their hair, mak­ ing artificial streaks iii front, or change the c o l o r completely ? 
2 Let their fingernails grow so long they look like claws aud then paint them silver or blood red? 
:l Soak themselves with perfume that almost knocks you dead when they walk liy ? 
I Wear so much eye makeup they look likt' Halloween spooks? 
What are these girls trying to prove 

 anyway? — Just Askin 

Dear .LA.: They are trying to prove they are grown-up — poor things. 

T h a n k s for writing. A letter from you will mean a lot more than “ advice from Granny Annie. 

Dear Ann Landers: 
I gave my daughter a lovely w ristw atch for 
Christmas. When I went to see her yesterday I noticed she was wearing her old one. 
I asked. “ What happened to the watch.! gave you?" She replied. “ My mother-in-law has it." 
I felt as if I had been slapped iii the face. 
When my son-in-law came home I asked him how come his motlier had the watch I had given to his wife. Ile shot buck. “ Because I gave it to her. 
I s a i d . “ I didn t give the watch to 
YOU. I gave it to your wife." He re­ 

 p l i e d . “ When you give something 

 a v v a v . it s not yours ain more. 
Is lie right'.* — Boiling Point 
Dear IS.IV. I he question is. who gave the watch away? lf your daughter did, remember not to buy her any more lovely gifts. lf it was your son-in-law. and he did it without his wife s jiermission, you have a right to be annoyed — and I feel sorry for her.

San Antonio .Junior League is hav ing its Reflections HI77 show at 7 p.m. 
Wednesday in Villita Assembly Build­ ing themed to “ A Day in the Hark." it will all he repealed the next night met buffet dinner by Don Strange aud dancing to the music of Larry Herman, dancing to the music of Larry Herman.

The San Antonio Symphony Society s 
String Quartet will give a debut per­ formance at the Oakuell home of Ro­ bert L. Tobin at 5 p.m. Sunday. 

Members are Julius Sc hill man. con­ certmaster. Nina I’osella, violin; Je r ­ ome Guilheau. viola; and Margaret 
Bella. cello Some 2IMI guests have been invited to this preview performance. 

It will he given iii an intimate, infor­ mal atmosphere iii which the guests are a nearby part of the scene. The quartet plans to play for other small audiences and to go into the s c h o o l s to demonstrate tile instruments later on.

By JEAN BAER 
AssertivenessTrain ing encourages wo­ men to recognize the value of being direct, honest, and non- manipulative. In this way you control your own communication. 
’I nu p u r s u e w hat you w ant directly an d d o n ’t h a v e to w a i t to see if others fall for your m a n ­ ipulative ploys. 

One AT te c h n i q u e to aid you in the expression of honest and appropriate emotion is I-Talk. This is my term. 

I b o r r o w e d it fro m p s y c h o l o g i s t 
Andrew 
S alte r's m o r e technical t e r m 
“ f e e l i n g t a l k . ” which is the “ deliberate u t t e r a n c e of s p o n t a n ­ eously felt emotions." It is a t e c h n i q u e th a t is specifically designed to aid p eo p le w ith d e f i ­ ciencies in the expression and experience of feeling. 

U s e o f I-talk 
1—Say what you want to say when you want to say it. W r it e s Andrew 
Salter. “ There is no harm in honoring social am en­ ities and ethical conven­ tions when they do not oppose our feelings. 
“ But we m u s t forgo premeditated utterances an d say w h a t we feel when we feel it. When a eat is happy, it purrs. 
When a dog has his paw stepped on, he howls. Let the inhibitory go and do likewise.” 
2—Say what you feel. 
At many times it is im ­ portant to say what you think, hut tliink-talk is not expression of feeling. 
S tate m e n ts about what you think reveal nothing of you. Make a distinction between verbs of feeling and thinking. 
FEE L IN G — cherish. adore, a p p r o v e , enjoy. get pleasure from, covet, long for, care for, hate, dislike, detest, despise, want. love. 
THINKING —■ suppose. g u es s, i m a g i n e , u n d e r ­ stand. believe, conclude, p r e s u m e , d e d u c e , a s ­ s u m e . t h i n k , l e t ’s go. verbalize, let’s discuss, let’s put our minds to the problem. 
3—Deliberately use the pronoun "I" us much as possible. Follow thi* with a feeling verb. 
“ I want to pay the bill this tune." 
“ I like this beef stew 

“ I cried over what you said to m e last night. 
T in a f r a i d of you when you show so much hostility.” 
“ I d on’t care for the way you always show up lute.*’ 

E x e r c i s e s 

4—If you have trouble using the pronoun “ I.” two AT e x e r c is e s m ay help. a-*Count the number of times >ou use “ I” in the c o u r s e of a day. You might want to invest in a golf counter and click it each tim e you get th e word out. Keep score. b—Make a deliberate attempt to use the follow­ ing three pairs of phrases as often as possible; 
—“ I agree with what yoil've said" . . . “ dis­ agree with what you’ve said." 
—"I want you to do this." “ I don’t want you to do that." 
—“I want to do this” . . 
. “ I d o n ’t w ant to do that.” 
Iii using t h e m , s t a rt with the easiest for you 
(many women find the “ I agree” . . . “ I disagree" simpler than the “ I want you to do this” . . . “ I d o n ’t w an t you to do th at"), keep a daily count and total weekly. After a few weeks analyze jo u r progress. 
I sing 1-Talk will not 

, ■ ,,, 

/ ' ' n 
' ■ 
* 

Are you a woman 
:■ 
Q or a mouser 

Part IV 

- 

 make you seem self-cen­ tered. It will m a k e you sound d i r e c t , n a t u r a l , and enable you to take that mask off your face. 

S e e t h i n g 

5— 
—D o n ’t s i m u l a t e agreeability when you’re seething inside. Esc sen­ tences like. “ I feel hu rt” . 
. . “ I d o n ’t like w hat you've said" . . . "I feel you have no right to talk to me like that." 
Often people don’t rea­ lize t h e y ’ve m a d e you angry. 
6— In expressing your feelings, m ake sure you express them ap pro­ priately. Expressing your feelings directly doesn’t mean a complete loss of control. 
7—In expressing your feelings, make sure you u n d e r s t a n d t h e d i f f e r ­ ence between a request and a d e m a n d . It h as nothing ti* do with the way you phrase a q u e s ­ tion. 
It h a s to do w ith whether, in your ex p e c­ tancy. you are giving the other person the right to say no. 
If you say. “ I would like Chinese food tonight. 
Mow do you feel about it?," this can he either a request or demand. lf ho/she says no and you feel disappointed or u n h a p p y , it w a s a r e ­ quest. Even though you don't like the answer, yon recognized the p erso n ’s right to refuse. 
If y o u r r e a c t i o n is a n g e r , d e p r e s s i o n , a feeling of h u m il ia t io n , then it was a dem an d . 
You a r e t h i n k i n g . 

 d —M a k e g e s t u r e s . 
Show emotions w ith your hands and a r m s as the 
F r e n c h do. 
You can pound a table for empha- 
P P f sis. You can put y o u r a r m s around the othe r person to show warmth. e —M a k e y o u r voice s trong and sure. Some people think a little, soft 
“ He/she should have said whisper means feminini- vos ” tv. and Ja c k ie Bouv ier 
8—Suit your actions to Onassis certainly gets your words. I-Talk also away with this, involves body and facial 
But b a b y -v o ic e d wo- talk. men — when it s an ob- a —Eye contact. Look viously assumed tone — straight at the person to often annoy rather than whom you a r e talk in g, attract people. 
Don't try to give those coy little glances that some w o m en m i s t a k e for fe­ m i n i n i t y . b—Match y o u r facial e x p r e s s i o n to y o u r f e e l i n g s ; d o n ’t s m i r k when you express anger. 
Don't look aw ay when you say "I ca re." e —S ta n d p ro u d . T h e way you stand influences the way you feel about yourself. 

 f—Your clothes are an­ o t h e r w ay of s a y i n g 
**I” — “ T h i s is w h a t I a m . ” C e r t a i n o u t f i t s m a k e a s s e r t i v e s t a t e ­ ments. When I feel in a blue mood. I try to wear a f a v o r ite r e d P a r i s i a n pants suit. 
It gives me confidence, and wearing it m a k es it easier for m e to say. “ I want" . . . “ I won’t." 

By p r a c t i c i n g 1-Talk you learn the skill of ex­ p r e s s i o n of f e e lin g s . 
E v e n t u a l l y you won t need to p r a c t i c e . T h e skill will he automatic. and you will have deve­ loped your own style of saving. "I want you to" .. 
“ I don’t want you to.”

S A N A N T O N IO E X P R E S S — W e d nesday. Mjarch_2_1 9 7 7 
Firings blamed on belly dance 

To have your problem solved or a ques- 
Hon answered, write Action-Express. TAK 
Box 217In San Antonio* TX 7H2<I7. 

Civil Hights 

 ll seems that recently tile papers have been full of civil rights news articles. 
There have been Supreme Court decisions, al­ locations in colleges arid universities, suits now pending in federal and county courts — all promot­ ing civil rights for blacks and Mcxican-Americans. 
Does everyone have civil-rights or just blacks and 
Mexican-Americans? I am Anglo, do I have civil rights 
Who investigates civil rights violations in San 
Antonio? Who could I contact to find out if my rights have been v iolatedo 

It B. 

WHAT 
ASCOT tAY 
CIVIL 
RIG H TS 

As you may have no­ ticed, there has lately been a rash of suits from 
Anglo-Americans charg­ ing “ reverse discrimina­ tion” in cases where m inority recruitm ent programs have allegedly passed over more-qualified Anglos in an attempt to increase the number of minority workers, students etc. 

Theoretically, the civil 

 rights of all American citizens are guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. 

However. because blacks and other minori­ ties had been 

 system atically denied voting rights, equal 

 educational opportunities and other opportunities open to Anglo-Amer­ icans. special laws were passed requiring that states, schools, compan­ ies and others guarantee that all Americans have the same opportunities. 

Those laws were 

 necessary because of the problems blacks and other minorities encoun­ tered in exercising all their rights as citizens. 

Anglos generally e\- 

 cercised full civil rights without question, so no special focus was needed to guarantee rights for 
A nglos. 

Now. however, that 

 may be changing as 
Anglos protest some of the methods used to in­ crease minority par­ ticipation in factory jobs, colleges and government posts. 
The U.S. Commission 

 on Civil Rights will in­ vestigate 
ANY allegations of civil rights violations from ANY I .S. citizen. Certainly, the 

 mechanisms of govern­ ment are designed lo protect everyone. 

The U.S. Department 

 of Justice and its inves­ tigative arm — the F B I 
— will probe any legi­ timate federal civil 

 rights violation com­ plaints. 

C ivil rights leaders, 

 however, have stressed repeatedly that the 

 granting of full civ il rights to minorities does not. in any way. diminish the civil rights of the m ajority. C ivil rights laws and lawsuits are merely designed to as­ sure that all Americans have the same rights, privileges and opportuni­ ties. 

However, when it 

 comes down to jobs, col­ lege placement and other matters, the effort to as­ sure equality may, for a time, seem unequal until the channels are all open to every American and special recruitment etc. is no longer necessary to make sure everyone has an equal chance. 

You must also 

 remember that blacks and others have been left out of jobs, colleges, houses, good schools and other opportunities by deliberate design over decades and decades — frequently in the form of state laws. Now. there must be a deliberate ef­ fort made to correct the results of all those years of forced exclusion. 

But, again, if you feel 

 your civil rights are be­ ing violated, the same agencies which help 

 minorities will also assist the majority. 

By DEBORAH W E S E R 

Studying belly dancing during lunch hours was the reason three women were fired from a Bexar 
County agency, a suit filed Tuesday claimed in blist District Court. 

The women, all former 
Bexar County Mental 
Health/Mental Retarda­ tion employes, said in their suit they were fired 
.July 24. 1975. by Execu­ tive Dir. Aaron Liberman for enrolling in a belly dancing class during their lunch hours. 

The suit claims they were fired because of the type of dancing they chose. Since usually only women belly dance, this const itutes d iscrim in a­ tion because of their sex, the. women claim. 

The petition says their employer said they were fired for attending classes during working hours 

Their petition in s is ts the discharges came without warning, hearing or other rights they are entitled to under an ex­ isting grievance proce­ dure tin' agency uses. 

The complainants al­ lege the discharges violate their consitution­ al rights of free speech, association and privacy. 
The suit aims directly at Liberman as chief of­ ficer of MH/MR and asks 

 reinstatement, full back pay and damages for loss of professional standing and embarrassment 
The three com plain­ ants are Mrs. Debra So­ lis. a home training supervisor since Dec. I.

2-year-old g irl who drowned Monday will be at IO a.m. Wednesday at 
Holy 
Spirit 
Catholic 
( liurch. 
Deputy M edical E x ­ aminer F. Clark Odum has ruled accidental drowning in the death of 
Usa Talley, 12o Village 
(reek. 
Survivors include her parents. Mr. and Mrs. 
Pat T alley, two and brothers. Patrick. Darin and Jeff, all of San An­ tonio. 

Burial will be 
Cross Cemetery. in Holy 

1973: Carolina L. Gomez, caseworker employed in 
Septem ber. 1972. and 
Ester Escobedo, home trainer in the Child De­ velopment 
Unit. em-.. ployed since March 17, 
1972. 
The suit states they at­ tended belly dancing classes at the YWCA for about two weeks, going during their lunch hour break. 

A. E. “ E D ” FLORA 
. . . rosary due today 

Hospital official’s rites set 

Funeral services have been set for 
Southwest Methodist Hospital execu­ tive A. E. “ Ed" Flora. 
Flora died unexpectedly Tuesday. 
Rosary will be recited at 7 p.m. 
Wednesday at Riebe-Saunders Funeral 
Home, 1119 N. St Mary’s St. 
Mass w ill be said at 12:3o p.m. 
Thursday at 
St. 
Luke’s 
Catholic 
Church. 
Flora had been with Methodist since 
June, 1975, as vice president. He was 

 previously employed for 14 years as vice president and general manager of the Nix Professional Building Corp. 

He is survived by his widow , Virgin­ ia and five children. 
A graduate of St. Mary's University. 
Flora was a former member of the 
Young Men’s Christian Assn. board of directors and was active in the San 
Antonio Lions Club and the Greater 
San Antonio Chamber of Commerce. 

Rites set for band director 

Services for Erhard Rimier, HL will be af noon 
Wednesday in St. Gregory's Catholic Church. 

Rimier, who died Sunday, served as band director for Catholic Schools in San Antonio for 2o years. 

Ruiner was born in Seguin and was graduated from Southwest Texas State University. 

He served as an officer in tho U.S. N a v y during 
World War II and won distinguished flying cross and gold star medals. 

The band director was a member of the Texas 
Band Masters Assn., Knights of Columbus, Art 
Publications Society of St. Louis and the American 
Legion of Bexar County. 

Survivors include his wife. Nadine Rimier of San 
Antonio: son, David Rim ier of San Antonio; daughters. Mrs. Linda Westrioh of Houston. Mre. 
Karen Jensen of Houston; Patricia Rimier of San 
Antonio and Rebecca Rimier of San Antonio. 

Also a sister. Mrs. Margaret Krause of San 
Antonio; brother, P’hilip Pinner of San Antonio and five grandchildren. 
Burial will be in Ft. Sam 
Houston National Cemetery. 

Credit talk today 

The legal right of women to obtain credit iii their own n am es will be discussed at an open meeting at 7 p.m. Wednesdav in Room 1o2 of St. Marv's Univer­ sity Law Library. 
The meeting is sponsored by the St. Mary s 
Women’s Law Assn 
Tin' speaker will be Dr. Marianne McCarthy, director of continuing education and summer ses­ sions at Trinitv University.

99 

At the moment of need, there is little opportunity to compare the staff and services of various funeral homes. When the selection is made for immediate service, cost com­ parisons are unavailable — and often not even considered by emotionally upset family members. 
For these reasons, we urge you to 

• • • 

 learn about Sunset prior to need . . . to consider our full funeral service and full family protection. Some practical pre-planning for “someday” is sensible now.

Funeral Home • Sunset Memorial 
Park • Sunset Mausoleums • Sunset 
Flower Shop.

Blow drier 

I recently bought a HiMi-watt hair dryer with 
“ Super Power ” and am having a big fight with my folks about it. They are screaming alwiut high utility bills and have gotten on this energy conservation kick. 
I hey harp and scream that America is going to have a massive blackout if we don't stop using things Uke blow dryers and electric toothbrushes and blenders and can-openers. 
So I ain willing to pay them for the use of my blow dryer, hut I can t figure out how much it is supposed lo Im* I called City Public Service and they told me 
HUO watts a month would cost about $23, 
That seems high Is that the right price?

Firings blamed on belly dance

Civil R ights 

It seems that recently the papers have been full of civil rights nous articles. 
There have been Supreme Court decisions, al­ locations in colleges and universities, suits now pending in federal and county courts — all promot­ ing civil rights for blacks and Mcxican-Amcricans. 
Does everyone have civil rights or just blacks and 
Mexican-Americans? I am Anglo, do I have civil rights 
Who investigates civil rights violations in San 
Antonio? Who could I contact to find out if my rights have been violated? 
R. B. 

WHAT 
C IV IL 
A6CUT J A Y 
R IG H TS S» 

As yea may have ne­ ck ed , there has lately been a rash of suits from 
Anglo-Americans charg­ ing “reverse discrimina­ tio n ” in cases where m inority recruitm ent programs have allegedly passed over more-qualified Anglos in an attem pt to increase the number of minority workers, students etc. 

Theoretically, the civil rights of all American citizens are guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution. 

However, because blacks and other minori­ ties had been system atically denied voting rights, equal educational opportunities and other opportunities open to A nglo-A m er­ icans. special laws were passed requiring that states, schools, compan­ ies and others guarantee that all Americans have the same opportunities. 

Those laws were necessary because of the problem s blacks and other minorities encoun tered in exercising all their rights as citizens. 

Anglos generally ex ­ ercised full civil rights without question, so no special focus was needed to guarantee rights for 
Anglos. 

Now, however, that may be changing as 
Anglos protest some of the methods used to in­ crease m inority par­ ticipation in factory jobs, colleges and government posts. 
The U.S. Commission on Civil Rights will in­ vestigate 
ANY allegations of civil rights violations from ANY U.S. citizen . Certainly, the 

 m echanisms of govern­ ment are designed to protect everyone. 

The U.S. Department of .Justice and its inves­ tigative arm — the FBI 
— will probe any le g i­ tim ate federal civil rights violation com ­ plaints. 

Civil rights leaders, however, have stressed repeatedly that the granting of full civil rights to minorities does not. in any way. diminish the civil rights of the m ajority. Civil rights laws and law suits are merely designed to as­ sure that all Americans have the sam e rights, privileges and opportuni­ ties. 

However, when 
It comes down to jobs, col­ lege placement and other matters, the effort to as­ sure equality may. for a time, seem unequal until the channels are aft open to every American and special recruitment etc. is no longer necessary to make sure everyone has an equal chance. 

You must also rem em ber that blacks and others have been left out of Jobs, co lleg es, houses, good schools and ether opportunities by deliberate design ever decades and decades — frequently in the form of state laws. Now. there must be a deliberate ef­ fort made to correct the results of all those years of forced exclusion. 

But. again, if you feel your civil rights are be­ ing violated, the sam e agencies which help minorities will also assist the majority. 

By DEBORAH WESER 

Studying belly dancing during lunch hours \*as the reason three women were fired from a Bexar 
County agency, a suit filed Tuesday claimed in blist District Court. 

The women, all former 
B exar County M ental 
H ealth/M ental R etard a­ tion employes, said in their suit they were fired 
July 24, 1975. by Execu­ tive Dir. Aaron Liberman for enrolling in a belly dancing c lass du rin g their lunch hours. 

The suit claim s they were fired because of the type of d a n cin g they chose. Since usually only women belly dance, this const it ut es d is c rim in a ­ tion because of their sex. the women claim. 

The petition says their employer said they were fired for a tte n d in g classes during working hours. 

Their petition insists the d isc h a rg e s cam e without warning, hearing or other rights they are entitled to under an ex­ isting grievance proce­ dure the agency uses. 

The com plainants a l­ lege the d is c h a rg e s violate their consitution­ al rights of free speech, association and privacy. 
The suit aims directly at Liberman as chief of­ ficer of MH/MR and asks 

 reinstatement, full back, pay and damages for loss of professional standing and embarrassment. 
The th re e c o m p la in ­ ants are Mrs. Debra So­ lis, a home tra in in g supervisor since Dec. I,

A. E. “ED” FLORA 
. . . rosary due today 
Hospital official’s rites set 

Funeral services have been set for 
Southwest Methodist Hospital execu­ tive A. E, “E d ” Flora. 
Flora died unexpectedly Tuesday. 
Rosary will be recited at 7 p.m . 
Wednesday at Riebe-Saunders Funeral 
Home. 1119 N. St. Mary’s St. 
Mass will be said at 12:3ft p.m . 
Thursday at 
St. 
Luke’s 
Catholic 
Church. 
Flora had been with Methodist since 
June, 1975. as vice president. He was 

 previously employed for 14 years as vice president and general manager of the Nix Professional Building Corp. 

He is survived by his widow , Virgin­ ia and five children. 
A graduate of St. Mary’s University, 
Flora was a form er m em ber of the 
Young Men’s Christian Assn. board of directors and was active in the San 
Antonio Lions Club and the G reater 
San Antonio Chamber of Commerce. 

Rites set for band director 

Services for Erhard Rimier. HI. will be at noon 
Wednesday in St. Gregory’s Catholic Church. 

Rinner, who died Sunday, served as band director for Catholic Schools in San Antonio for 2o years. 

Rinner was born in Seguin and was graduated from Southwest Texas State University. 

He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy during 
World War ll and won distinguished flying cross and gold star medals. 

The band director was a member of the Texas 
Band Masters Assn., Knights of Columbus. Arf 
Publications Society of St. Louis and the American 
Legion of Bexar County. 
. t i * 
♦ 
Survivors include his wife. Nadine Rinner of San 
Antonio; son. David R inner of San Antonio: daughters. Mrs. Linda Westrich of Houston, Mrel 
Karen Jensen of Houston; Patricia Rinner of Salt 
Antonio and Rebecca Rinner of San Antonio. 

Also a sister. Mrs. M argaret Krause of San 
Antonio; brother. Philip Rinner of San Antonio and five grandchildren. 
Burial will be in Ft. Sam 
Houston National Cemetery. 

Credit talk today 

The legal right of women to obtain credit in their own names will be discussed at an open meeting at 7 p.m. Wednesday in Room 1o2 of St. Mary’s Univer­ sity Law Library. 
The meeting is sponsored by the St. M ary’s 
Women’s Law Assn. 
The speaker will be Dr. Marianne McCarthy, director of continuing education and summer ses­ sions at Trillitx I nivorsity.

99 

At the moment of need, there is little opportunity to compare the staff and services of various funeral homes. When the selection is made for immediate service, cost com­ parisons are unavailable — and often not even considered by emotionally upset family members. 
For these reasons, we urge you to 

• • • 

 learn about Sunset prior to need . . . to consider our full funeral service and full family protection. Some practical pre-planning for “someday” is sensible now.

Park • Sunset Mausoleums • Sunset 
Flower Shop.

Funeral Home

However, he agreed lo move the trailer to the hack yard. 
Now. see, wasn't that easy ? 
Your neighbor, bv the wav. says if you had bothered lo com e over and ask him to move the trailer, he would have done so. He didn't reveal vour identity at all. but he knew im m ediately who wrote the letter 

FAN ANTONIO 
RORCieiTATlON

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesdoy March 2 1977_______ Page 
I C 
Vale drops own bill, aids Good Neighbor 
Hollywood Park hit by heart attack suit 

A Hollywood Park man has filed a $225.IMM) suit against the suburb and a 
Hollywood Park police­ man for a dispute he al­ leges caused him to have a heart attack. 
Saunders Ray Bynum of the inn block of Canyon 
Creek filed the suit in district court a g a in st 
Hollywood Park and Pa­ trolman Richard Miller. 
The suit alleges the suburb issued an arrest warrent against Bynum last Aug. 19 on a charge he violated a building code. 
A week later Miller ar­ rested Bynum, according to the suit, by handcuff­ ing him and treating him roughly despite Bynum protests he had recently had open heart surgery and was having trouble breathing. 
A spokesman of the town declined comment. 

 first time ever 

REP. BOB VALE 
. . . kills own hill 

Council (elections are next month) passes a re­ solution to include the rate payer in the settle­ ment should any money be award(xl. 
The present city coun­ cil has already done so. 
Vale said.

Navarro Room.

Skeletal find is kitchen refuse 

• I O-digit printout 

• automatic item count w / grand total 

• dual percent mode for straight percentages or 

 add-on / discount 

• constants for multiplication & division 

• red print for subtraction & negative numbers 

Skeletal remains discovered last week at a res­ toration site at Nueva and Presa streets, just west of 
Lu Villita, have been classified us middens — trash. 
The bones proved to be chicken bones, soup bones and other kitchen refuse. 
“ They are the kind of thing found outside back doors of most early San Antonio homes." said Mrs. 
Anne Fox. research archaeologist at the Iniversity of Texas at San Xntonio. 
“ It wasn't until after the Civil War that garbage was collected in San Antonio." she said. “ This home had a pit dug into the ground which was gradually filled with trash." 
UTSA archaeologists have not analyzed the exact date of the bones. Mrs. Fox san 1. 
Victor Martinez, with a crew hind by the San 
Antonio Conservation Society, found the bones 
Thursday afternoon. 
“ The crew was digging for (foundation) footings for a wall when the bones were found." said Mrs. 
Barbara Lucked. chairman of the restoration pro­ ject 
The full report is expected within It) days.

Mart posts best gain of ’77

F E B R U A R Y 

Stock Market Graphic Features 

M AR 

N E W Y O R K (A P ) - 
The stock market ran up its best gain of the year 
Tuesday, pushing the 
Dow .Jones industrial average up 8.31 points to 
94173. 
The Dow. although up modestly Monday, has been in a downtrend for most of early 1977. The last time the average turned in a better show­ ing was Dec. 27. when the 
Dow climbed 1o.47. 
Gainers outpaced losers by a 5-2 margin on the New York Stock Ex­ change. 
Morning trading was halted for more than an hour after a minor fire broke out on the trading floor. About 2,5oo people 
B iis in e s s a n d P ln a n c e 

 were evacuated because of the smoke, but no in­ juries were reported. The 
N YSE said damage was minimal. 
Volume up 

Despite the interrup­ tion, Big Board volume increased to 19.48 million shares from Monday’s three-month low of 16.22 million. 
The market’s rally was a combination of internal factors and outside en­ couragement. including 
President Carter's denial of rumors he was plan- ning a gasoline tax in­ crease as high as 25-cents a gallon. 
“ The market is an in­ ternal dynamic animal.” observed Larry Wachtel of Bache Halsey Stuart. 
“ Seventy-five per cent of the time it goes up and 

 down of its own volition. 
If the market has gone down six days in a row, it usually rallies.” 
However, others cau­ tioned that investors, still lacking confidence and afraid of more inflation, were watching the out­ come of the proposed 
$69.8 billion federal bud­ get deficit. 
Picked up 

Standard & Poor's in­ dex of 4oo industrial stocks picked up .98 to 
112.o5, and 
S & P ’s 
5oo-stock composite in­ dex rose .84 to I OO. HH. 
The strongest group 
Tuesday was the in­ dependent oil and gas stocks, reacting to the 
Federal Power Commis­ sion’s announcement of plans to consider higher 

 prices for new natural gas. 
As the 4 p.m. close of the NYSE. Reserve Oil & 
Gas was up 1% to 18; 
Inexco Oil. I -Ti to 19%; 
Woods Petroleum, I Va to 
25%; Wilshire Oil, •% to 
8%; and P atrick P e ­ troleum, 1% to 12%. 
Houston Oil climbed 3 to 
46%, topping the 
Am erican 
Stock 
Exchange’s most active list. 

The most active 
NYSE-issue was General 
M ills, up % to 29*%. A block of 375,1oo shares was sold at 29%. 
American Broadcast­ ing, boosted by higher television ratings, reported increased fourth-quarter and full year profits. ABC was up 
•% at 39%. 

The N Y SE ’s composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 
.45 to 54.88. 
On the Amex, the mar­ ket value index rose.88 to 
111.13. 
The NASD AQ composite index for over-the-counter market closed at 95.14. up .57.

Office Space 

45 Sq. Ft. * Prestige Location 

N orth w e st 
Call 3 49-1453 

Computer money transfer nears 

W A SH IN G TO N (A P ) - The day when you can shop with a computer card rather than your purse drew 
(•loser Tuesday when a federal study commission gave its qualified ap­ proval to new computerized ways of transferring money. 
The Commission on Ele ctro n ic 
Funds Transfers concluded after 13 months of study that the computerized payment devices “ could benefit con­ sumers in a number of significant ways. but only if certain crucial fea­ tures and safeguards are built into the system" to protect individuals against the danger of invasion of privacy. 
The electronic devices are designed to transfer money between accounts without any paper such as cash or a check changing hands. 
Deducted from account 
For example, a customer at a store could insert a plastic “ debit card” into a machine and the amount of his pur­ chase would automatically be deducted from his bank account and deposited in the store’s account. 
Among conveniences to consumers would be the need to carry less cash. 

 opportunity for greater use of credit and increased ability to transfer mon­ ey from noninterest-bearing accounts to interest-bearing accounts, the 
26-member commission said. 
The commission received about 6,ooo letters and petitions from consumers, almost all of them expressing ap­ prehension about the new technology. 
“ Consumers are more concerned about the drawbacks of electronic funds transfers than about potential ben­ efits," the commission’s report noted. 
Increasing impact 

Nevertheless, it concluded that the electronic devices inevitably will have an increasing impact on consumers. 
“ The role of computers in money and banking will become increasingly ap­ parent to consumers. It is time, there­ fore. for government to develop a co­ herent policy toward E F T services and systems." the commission said in its 
149-page report. 
It recommended that all stores and banks that want to offer debit-card service be allowed to do so. It said that competition between companies will 

C oastal in co m e up 

Coastal States Gas Corp. Tuesday 

 reported a net income of $58.4 mil­ lion for the full year 1978. 

This resulted in earnings per 

 share of $2.8o on average shares or 
$2.67 on a fully diluted basis, the company said. 

Comparable 1975 net income was 

$54.3 million and earnings per share 

 were $2.59 on average shares and 
$2.5o fully diluted. 

The company also reported total 

 revenues of $2.3 billion for 1976 compared to $1.9 billion for 1975. 

The company's directors also set 

May IO as the date for the com­ pany's 1977 annual meeting of stockholders and fixed the record date for determining shareholders entitled to vote at March 16, 1977. 

 assure the convenience of consumers is maintained. 
However, the new payment system also makes possible unprecedented in­ vasions of individual privacy, it said. 
This is possible through development of computer data banks that can store data on all electronic transactions made by a consumer. 
Reconstruct details 
Government investigators could reconstruct many details of a person’s private life through such records. 
Therefore, the commission recom ­ mended laws requiring advance no­ tification to the individual of any sub­ poena or summons by the government involving records of his transactions. 
In addition, under the commission’s proposal, individuals would be able to contest in court the government’s ac­ cess to the records. 
The commission also recommended a law against commercial use of any information about a consumer's tran­ sactions without his consent. This would prevent, for example, sale of 
'records on a person’s purchases for use in compiling mailing lists. 
IGC raps m oving firm 

Sherwood Van Lines, 
Inc., 4322 Milling Road, has been ordered to pay 
$2,69o in forfeiture claims for violations of tile Interstate Commerce 
Act. 
The Interstate Com ­ merce Commission said the forfeiture claims in­ volved Sherwood Van 
Lines transporting hou­ sehold goods beyond the territorial scope of the certificate issued to it by the K ‘C. 

“ Before consumers w ill accept tech­ nological innovations such as E F T . they must be assured that the infor­ mation maintained and stored by depository institutions will not be used without appropriate restrictions and protection." the commission said. 

White wants food priority 

AUSTIN (A F ) — Food may not always be a dependable and renewable resource if the nation doesn’t place agriculture among its highest priori­ ties. Texas Agriculture Commissioner 
John C. White said Tuesday. 

“ Time is running out on assurances that food will always be a dependable and renewable resource, unless we as a nation establish high priorities for agricultural needs." said White at a 
Minneapolis. Mum., farm forum.

Ready tor rain 
With his land worked. 
Max Topperwcin now is ready for 5o inches to un inch of ruin al his place near Moore. 
Toepperwein said he has worked out the lumps in the so il. Ile intends to plant sudan and other grasses for his dairy cows. 
During the long rainy spell he quit looking ut tile land when it got too muddy. 
Clayton 
Nester of 
D Hams remarked Mon­ day that the winds have dried out the soil around 
D'Hanis at a rapid rate. 
He said some of the land owners would be wanting rain in another week or two. 
Ile added that some of the land owners are I Hiss 

 getting their fields into shape. 
Tuesday was a quiet day at the Union Stock 
Yards, with receipts es­ timated at 5oo cattle and 
2oo hogs. 
Totals for the week were estimated at 3.125 cattle and 1.ooo hogs 
Figures for the first two days last week were 
3.946 cattle and 1.839 hogs and for a co rre­ sponding two days in 1976 were 5,125 cattle and 586 hogs.

INVESTMENT COURSE 

Conducted by FRANK TINNEY, President, R. I. Stewart & Co. Inc. 

The course consists of 4 sessions. The first will include a frank discussion of today's economy, prices, interest rates and the current investment outlook. 

Later sessions will include taxable and tax-exempt bonds, tax-deferred annuities, stocks, funds, and a special discus­ sion on how to make an investment plan to fit your own personal situation. 

Content will be simple, candid and without sales solici­ tation. Each class will include time for questions. The price is a $5 donation (per family) to any charity.

KTTKX Of INTBmON TO ISSUE CERTIFICATES OF OBLIGATION 
TAKE NOTICE that lf** City Council of tho City/of San 

Antonio, Texas, proposes to issue and sell for cosh Ceitificates of Obligation of said City in an amount not to exceed 
$4,oooX1oo for the purpose of obtaining funds to pay con­ tractual obligations to be incurred for the construction of cer­ tain improvements and additions to the City of Son Antonio, 
Texas, Convention Center Arena, and to pay architect’s tees, financial advisor's fees, legal fees and other incidental expenses incurred in connection therewith. The City Council tentatively proposes to author ire the issuance of said certi­ ficates or obligation in an ordinance to be passed ct o meet­ ing o f the said City Council on the 24th day of March, 19 7 7 , at I IOO o'clock A.M., said meeting to be held in the City 
Council Chambers, City Hall, Son Antonio. Texas. Provision will be made for the payment of said Certificates of Obliga­ tion at the time of their authorization by the levy and pledge of ad valorem taxes sufficient to pay the principal of said cer­ tificates as the some matures and the interest on said certifi­ cates as the same becomes doe, and to create the necessary and sufficient sinking fund as required by law; and payment of said Certificates o f Obligation *o be further secured by a pledge of the revenues received by the Qty from the opera 
* of the City af Son Antonio, Texas, Convention Center 
Arena, revenues received by the City from the operation of concessions in said Arena, revenues received by the City from the operation af certain parking facilities adjacent to the 
Arena (but not including revenues received from the operation af the Marino Garage), and revenues received by the City from the levy o f a hotel occupancy lox, such pledge of reve­ nues to be mode in such manner that additional securities may 
•nailer be issued by the City of San Antonio, Texos, se­ cured by o Ken on and pledge of the said revenues on a parity and equal dignity with the pledge securing these proposed certificates of obligation. 

THIS NOTICE is given pursuant to the provisions of Article 
2368a I. Revised Civil Statutes of Texos

Spurs and Jazz could help L.A. 

If the neighbors of Jerry West get up early enough one morn­ ing they might see the Laker coach in his front yard, still wearing his pajamas. 

You see. the first thing Jerry does each day is run out and get the paper, turn to the sports section and glance at the NBA standings. 
Checking on his Lakers’ battle with 
Portland for the division lead, huh? 
Nope. West knows how his team fared the night before And he knows what Portland did Me is busy cheeking on the New Orleans Jazz And the San 
Antonio Spurs. 

With a lot of help from the Jazz and 
Spurs this season, the Lakers could wind up with two of the top college stars in the country next season. 

Los A ngeles is in an em ious position. 
The L akers have th ree first-round picks in the upcoming draft They ob­ tained New Orleans' No. I pick in the 
(iail Goodrich deal prior to the season and then picked up the S p u rs' top choice a few months ago in that (sorry to remind you) Mack Calvin transac­ tion. 
West is realistic and, therefore, does not expect the Spurs to finish with among the worst records in the league. 
Still, the lower the Spurs finish tin1 higher West will get to pick in the draft. 
Jerry is optimistic about his draft choice from the Jazz Hight now only a few team s have worst records than 
New O rleans and by the end of the season the Jazz could easily have the third worst record in pro basketball — m eaning the L akers would get the third player chosen iii the draft 
Rudy Davalos. former Spur assistant who is now athletic director at I TSA, is scouting for the Spurs. Rockets and 
Lakers so he is also interested in how low New Orleans finishes this season. 
“ The Lakers have a chance to really help their club." says Davalos, who was the speaker al the Tipoff Club 
I unche< rn yeste rd ay. 

Won t be easy 

Davalos points out that it won t he easy for a college player to make a pro team next year because tor all practi­ cal purposes the league had two drafts prior to this season. 
The NBA had the re g u la r college draft and. later, it had a special draft of ABA players who were not included in the merger. 
“ That was the same as two drafts because about 18 ABA players were picked up." explains Davalos. “ It will 
Im1 hard for a young player out of col­ lege beating out one of those exper­ ienced guys from the ABA. 
“ T h e re a re som e ex c e p tio n s, of course There are a few who will make it for sure. But al the most, I would guess thai no m ore than 25 college plays make ti next year. Maybe not that many." 

Because several underclassmen quit school to turn pro when (lie money was good prior lo last year's merger, this season's college crop is weaker than usual. 

A lso, not as many college stars will go the hardship route now because there is no bidding war for young ta­ lent. They are better off staying iii college, getting a tree education ain' improving their skills 
“ Look at last year.” says Davalos. 
“ Of the No I picks. IK made it. Only nine second-round picks made it. only four th ird -ro u n d e rs , two fourth- ro u n d e rs, one fifth -ro u n d e r, two six th -ro u n d e rs and one seventh- rounder. Nobody iii the eighth, ninth or tenth rounds made ii 
“ And thai w as with IS learns draft­ ing. This year there will In* 22 It will drop off even more. I predict that no­ body will m ake it a fte r the fourth round." 

Reid and Leggett 

 indiana s Kent Benson and JLI LA's 
Marques Johnson are said to be the only two college eagers with potential to start in the NBA next season. 
There are about 111 others who are great prospects 
•'There s lins kid from Minnesota by the name of Michael Thompson lie s 
8-Iii. real big lie s a junior but I hear he's planning to go hardship, lie s close to Benson, believes Davalos. 

Kansas City, thanks lo an earlier deal with New York. will pick first this year. assuming the Nets finish with the worst record And the Kings are anx­ ious to sign Benson because they need a center. 

Kicky Green ut Michigan is the top guard but Otis Birdsong of Houston is close behind. Davalos says. 
According lo Davalos. St Mary’s has two local players who will be taken somewhere down the line. 
’ I think Robert Real is the lx*st pro prospect st. M ary's has had. says 
Rudy. "I think In* will go iii the first three rounds. He's 8-8. can shoot from outside. 
“ And Leggett is a real smart guard who will be drafted lie w ont go as high as Reid. hut somebody should lake him .” 
Having donated their No. I pick to 
L A., maybe the Spurs would In* wise iii using their second-round pick to land Reid, who will Im* a semi-sleeper, 
Euless, of course, the Lakers pick lorn first 

Snakes’ road to KC ends in East T exas

Hot Sp urs 
(K)nick 
New York 

BY J E F F GROSSMAN 
O f THI EX PRISS STAM 

NEW YORK — The Spurs shot a sizzling 7o per cent from the field in the second half as they defeated the Knicks, 132-127, 
Tuesday night at 
Madison 
Square Garden. 

It was their second straight victory in the third of a five-game road trip, and their sixth road triumph in the last nine games. 

GROSSMAN 

The win unproved San Antonio's re­ cord to 34-28. and gave the Spurs their season series against New Y ork. 3-1 
Larry Kennn paced the S p urs w ith 3o points, while George 
Gervin added 28. But it w as Kenon s two successive steals that put the Spurs in the pink 
Butch B eard went past G ervin for a layup, and then Ticky 
Burden stole the^hall from 
“ I c e " ^“and scored to cut the- 
Spurs' lead to five, 118-113. with 2:3o to go 
The Spurs had led by as many as 12 
IMunts earlier in the quarter. 
But Kenon stole the ball from Bob 
McAdoo, and went iii unmolested for a slam dunk. Then he s t o l e the bull from 
Beard. Gervin missed a 14 footer from the lane, but K got the rebound and was fouled by Burden. 
His two free throws upped the lead to nine points xx 11Ii 2:o8 to go. and tile 
Kitieks were through. 
“ I could feel the tide change with th o se plays." said Kenon. "Playing in th e Garden didn t mean anything spe­ cial It was another road game. 
"B ut. if you fall behind here, it is realty hard to come back bacause the crowd g e ts behind th e ir team so much." 
Neither team led by more than eight until the Spurs went on a o-o tear mid- wav through the fourth quarter to open a 113-1o1 lead. 
Colly Dietrich started ll off with a baselin e ju m p e r. Ice c o n v e rte d a 

Burbank slips past 
Lee, 52-5o 

Bv JOHN HINES 
O f THE EXPRESS STAN 

The 
Burbank 
Bulldogs qualified for their second straight regional tournament with a 52-5o bidistrict thriller over the Lee Volunteers at 
Blossom Athletic Center Tues­ day night. 

HINES 

GILBERT SALINAS (5 5 ) of Burbank takes a rebound a w ay from Lee’s Chuck Stanley s ta ff p h o to by pat h a m ilto n 

Burbank now plays Kennedy at IO a.rn. Saturday to open the regional meet at BAC. Austin Reagan and Cor­ pus Christi Moody follow at noon, with the finals at 8 p.m. 
Austin R eagan upset d efen d in g regional champion Victoria. 8o-74 iii four overtim es, at Texas L utheran 
College, while Moody, regional fin­ alists last year, raced to a 78-72 victory over 
Mission. 
An overflow crowd of 3,2oo jam med into 
BAC and got th e ir m oney’s w orth and m ore, as the lead changed h an ds 
12 times, there were nine ties and only tw ice was there any kind of breathing room at all betw een the te a m . 
Burbank leading by five in the first and six in the second. 
Gilbert Salinas of Burbank picked up his fourth foul with 53 seconds left in the half, sat out the remaining time plus the entire third quarter, then re­ turned in the fourth period to help the 
Bulldogs win. 
The lead changed hands seven times in the last quarter, although there was only one point scored in the last 3:25 after Salinas put in a rebound to give 
Burbank a 51-5o margin. 
Ernest Puente, who missed two foul shots at the 1:37 mark, put in the first of a I-and-1 with 53 seconds left to complete the scoring. 
Salinas had two offensive rebounds to keep Burbank in possession and 
Puente ultimately hit two free throws to give the Bulldogs a 49-48 lead with 
5:o4 left, but Bill Bond hit from the top of the key for Lee with 3 3o remaining lo give the Vols their last margin at 
5o-49.

The 
St. 
Mary's Rattlers will not bo go­ ing to Kansas City this year. 

St. Mary's season came to a sudden end Tuesday night as 
East Texas State chewed up the 
Snakes, 25-9, in the final eight minutes to post a convincing 
72-5B win the East Texas State 
Fieldhouse. 

Last Texas advances to the NAIA 
Tournament next week iii Kansas City as the District Four champion. St. 
Mary's ends lls season with a 23-8 record. 
“ It s really a shame iii a way." said St. 
M ary 's 
Coach 
Ed 
Messbarger. "I really feel this team could have gone all the way. 
"T hey were incon­ sistent in the middle of the year, but really got tough n e a r the end. It ju st d id n 't work out for us." 
St. M ary’s held a 
32-28 halftime lead as 4,o5o fans kept the Lions’ den buzzing. The Rattlers made only six field goals in the second half. 
Last Texas, which switched from a zone to man-to-man at halftime, outs­ cored St Mary 's. 44-24. in the final 2o minutes. 
The game was tied for the last time al 47-47 and little did the Snakes know­ how close their season was to being over 
The Lions hung St. Mary's with its own rope when the Snakes came out iii a t'ullcourt press as they trailed by four points with just over five m inutes to play. 
ET made a mockery of the usually effective p re s s in g d efen se of the 
Rattlers, breaking open for numerous easy b uck ets and d ra w in g se v era l fouls. The Lions canned ll of 12 free throws in the last five minutes.

\ihi go “with what you think will work hest for you and I thought we could hurt them with our press. 
“They spread us out and got a lot of easy shots aud fouls and made the free throws. I thought we played them well defensively until then."

Last Texas a 58-51 lead, probably just about did in the R a ttle rs

PRESS-T3B 

ADOLPH COONS COMPANY • OCX.U IS COLCHADO WHO* 

"Press-Tab" adds a new dimension to the convenience and anti-litter benefits of the all aluminum recyclable can. 

PRESS-TAB ’ — completely eliminates ring-pull litter, as 
Press-Tab consists of a single tab that remains attached to the lid after opening The can remains one complete recy­ clable unit. 

Coors introduces Press-Tab as a voluntary corporate alter­ native to anti ring-pull legis­ lation now existing in some states, and which possibly could be introduced on a national level. 

Gently depress Tab with tode* linger 

‘Please hold the can at either top or bottom. 
Working Together for a Better Environment"

There will be 34 bouts Thursday at 
Municipal Auditorium un the San An­ tonio Regional Golden Gloves Boxing 
Tournament gets under way. 
Tho tourney will run through Satur­ day, with tlio action beginning each night at 7:3o. 
There is a diverse list of ticket prices for the annual event. Patrons can pur­ chase a $25 package for the entire tournament or pay $1o nightly. Re­ served ringside tickets are priced at $4 for Thursday or Friday and $3 for the finals on Saturday. 
Seats iii the orchestra section are $3 nightly and $2 for the balcony. All mi­ litary personnel will be admitted with a 4o per cent discount with their ID cards

Sam Houston, 
Baylor split 

HUNTSVILLE (AP) — Tommy Knox singled home the go-ahead as Sam 
Houston State rallied for 1o-7 college baseball victory over Baylor in the second game of a doubleheader Tues­ day after the Geary*on the first game 

4-n. 

Kennedy triumphs 

Continued from Page ID for stepping on the backbite and Jud­ son had another chance with 49 seconds left. 
Gary Rodgers sank a corner jump shot, reducing Judson's deficit to one, 
6(3-65. Rodgers had a chance to put hjs team ahead with 37 seconds left, but he missed on the front half of a one-and-one. 
Judson got three more chances after the missed free throw, but each effort went awry. Finally, Kennedy’s Frank­ lin Watley grabbed a rebound and threw a fulleourt pass to Bethley who scored on a layup with 14 seconds left. 
Following a three-point play by 
Bethley, who was the game’ leading scorer with 22 points, including IO in the fourth quarter. Judson’s Rodgers missed another effort from the free throw line with nine seconds left. 
“ The fans got their money’s worth," 
Judson Coach Don Perkins said, forc­ ing a smile. “ I am not going to if and but about it, though. We did not play w ell for three quarters. 
"Kennedy jumps and shoots so well. 
We could not keep them off the boards. 
And we could not hit our shots early. 
They are a more talented team. I am proud of our guys. They did not give up."

T exas Southern earns NAIA berth 

WICHITA F ALLS I AP) - Aloiuu 
Bradley scored 29 points lo lead Texas 
Southern to a 82-78 college basketball victory over Midwestern Tuesday night and give the Tigers a 2-o triumph iii a best-of-three NAIA Bist. VHI playoff series. 
Bradley and Michael Long both had 
Ii points in the second half to spark the 
TSL victory, 
Long. who finished with IT {joints, hit seven uf nine shots from the field as 
FSL fought off a second-half rally by 
Midwestern. 
Hie Tigers led 38*31 at halftime but 
Midwestern went ahead 43-41 on a bucket by Lari Gray with 18; 12 to play. 
Bul Long’s ihrec-pomt play with 15;38 left gave TSU the lead and the Tigers never trailed again. 
TSL is now 28-5 and will advance lo the NAIA tournament in Kansas Lily next week,

LL IIBIX K (A P) — Paul Johnston went three*for*lhree and scored three runs and his brother Murk picked up a victory with two innings of sliuioul relief as Texas Tech twat Hardin*sim mons 11*5 in the second game of t college baseball doubleheader Tut-* day. liardin-Simmons won the first gauit 
SM behind Allen Lakuita » two run single and two-run homer 

Outdoors 

 w i t h l i n n K l o p p o r 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Wednesday March 2 1977 
H 

Spurs outlast Knicks, 132-127 

Rio Grande perch and tilapia dying 

The cold winter is finally — or still — catching up with tilapia and Bio Grande perch, two warm-water fish which have be­ come increasingly numerous in 
Canyon Lake. 

Reports from scuba divers that fish are dying in Canyon prompted biolo­ gists with the Parks and Wildlife De­ partment to check the reservoir this week. They found a few Rio Grande perch and tilapia. 
The biologists also cheeked water temperatures at the two sites. North 
Park and Comal Park, divers reported dead fish. The surface temperature at 
North was 55. at Comal. 57 degrees. 
-This is nine degrees warmer than two weeks ago,” said biologist Jim iny 
Dean of San Antonio. " W e ’ve had water temperatures this year that should have killed a lot of tilapia and 
Rio (irandes. Maybe they have, and the water was so cold the fish didn t come to the surface." 

Dean said the appearance of dying fish now might be the result of the warm weather. "T h is spring-like weather might have coaxed the tilapia and Rio Grandes away from the un­ derwater springs and caught them with their pants down.’* he said. 

These two species of fish can become too abundant in some reservoirs. At 
Craning, for example, tilapia, which thrive in the warm water, are a real problem. 
Normally, the fish are kept in check by cold winters, because they cannot withstand frigid temperatures. How­ ever. Canyon has a number of under­ water springs where water tempera­ tures remain constant, and fish such as tilapia are able to survive the cold by rem aining iii the vicin ity of the springs, 
A .22 for a .3o-o6 

Remington has developed a .22 car­ tridge that will convert a .3o-oo into a flat shooting, small game gun with the highest bullet velocity ever produced in a factory-loaded round. 
The cartridge is called the “ Acce­ lerator." and it involves the use of a 
.224, 55-grain bullet inside a .3o-caliber sabot casting. A sabot is a thrust- transmitting carrier that positions the bullet in the barrel. 
The use of the Accelerator provides the owner of a manually operated (bolt or pump action) .3o-oo with a second caliber. The new cartridge will not operate the action of autoloading rifles 

 but will function shot basis. in them on a single 

Muzzle velocity from a 21-inch barrel is 4o8o fps for the Accelerator, which surpasses by 35o fps or more the velo­ city of any current factory-loaded .22 caliber cartridge with a 55-grain bul­ let. 

Muzzle energy of the cartridge is 
2o33 foot pounds, highest ever deve­ loped for a .22 caliber bullet. Reming- ston says that from zero to 2oo yards it is superior in energy to such heavier cartridges as the 3o-3o. .35 and 45-7o. 
Once the Accelerator cartridge’s sa- bot-encased bullet leaves the muzzle, air resistance peels open the sabot, causing it to drop off the bullet without affecting accuracy or trajectory. 
Compared to the .22o Swift with a 
48-grain bullet or the .22-25o with 
55-grain bullet, the Accelerator bas more velocity and more foot pounds of energy from the muzzle to 5oo yards and is flatter shooting over the same distance. 
Wednesday short shots 

(irant White of the Bait Hut on the 
Port Aransas causeway said he will offer $1oo to the fisherman who catches the heaviest black drum from his lighted pier between Saturday and 
April 15. 
The Bait Hut is located on the causeway between Aransas Pass and 
Port Aransas. White said only a very few catches of large drum have been made so far this winter, but it appears the fish are beginning to move into the channels. ir it it 
The 2oo-target Zone 5 International 
Skeet Warm Up will be held Saturday and Sunday at the National Gun Club. 
The shoot will be registered with the 
National Skeet Shooting Association. 
★ ★ it 
High Country Sports on San Pedro is offering kayaking lessons and canoe outings this year. Weekend canoe out­ ings on the Guadalupe are scheduled from the last of March through the middle of September. 
Persons interested should check with 
High Country. 15o54 San Pedro, for prices and dates.

That short pheasant season in 
Matagorda and Liberty Counties — the first ever beld iii the two coastal areas 
— resulted til a kill of 189 birds. 
Most of them — all but six — were taken in Matagorda County, where the 
Parks and Wildlife Department first released birds in 19W. The department said the hunt attracted 235 hunters.

McAdoo led the Knicks with 35 points, while Spencer Haywood, play­ ing for the first time in 23 games be­ cause of a leg injury, hit for 22. as did 
Earl Monroe. 

Dam pier and Bristow were both six-for-1o from the field, and scored 18 and 14, respectively. Center B illy

“ I know we gave up 127 points, but the defense made th£ offense go. Billy was awesome, and K ’s steals at the end were .Hist great." 

“ We had the Garden fever the first time, but not now.” smiled Gervin. 

“ The Knicks are such a pattern club." said Bristow. “ They take 15 seconds lust to get a perimeter shot. 
“ But the pressure defense seemed to confuse them. They kept trying to go 

 one-on-one. 
“ We’re not so much awed by places like here and the Boston Garden the second time around." said Dampier, explaining the improved road record. 

Now. it appears, the Spurs arc gam­ ing a little awe tor themselves.

D ET R O IT (A P ) - David Thompson scored 13 points during a 2o-point Denver streak in the fourth period and the Nuggets went on to whip the Detroit Pistons 11o-94 
Tuesday night in the NBA. 

It is official now: Peace finally conies lo the NFL 

Peace officially 
Football League 
NEW VORK (A P) came to the National 
Tuesday. 
Sargent Karsh, executive director of 
N FL Management Council, aud Ed 
Garvcv. head of the players ussoeia- tion. initialed a new five-year collec­ tive bargaining agreement. 
The signing ceremony was about an hour late but after the three-year negotiating tug of war thathpreeeded ii. nobody was concerned about the extra tit) minutes. 
The union membership, about Hi) per cent of the nearly 1.3o(1 N EL players. must still ratify lite agreement but 
Garvey and Leu lluuss of the W a­ shington Redskins, a vice president of the union, expect no problem there. 
“ I think the members will accept it wholeheartedly." said Gauss. “ The 
Redskin players I ve talked to like it and so do the player representatives ” 
Ballots will be mailed out next Mon* dav with the union estimating IO davs 

 for all the returns. Before that, how­ ever. the agreement will Ik* submitted for review next Friday to Judge Earl 
Larson iii Minnesota Federal Court. 
It was Judge Larson’s decision iii the 
John Mackey suit against the league that emphasized the conflict between the union and the owners. 
Management ratified the pact last week. “ We get stability and the ele­ ments of a new system that enables us to operate." said Willington Mara, owner of (he New York Giants and chairman ol the Management Council negotiating team. 
The contract will cost the 28 member dubs approximately $1o7 million iii the areas of four basic area—pensions. lawsuit settlements, insurance and post-season pay. Fringe improvements such as meal money, minimum sa­ laries. etc., will add lo the dollar value. 
Tile draft will in* a 12-round altair held on May I each year instead of 17 rounds in January, 

The Nuggets, winning for the seventh time iii the last eight outings and upping their overall re­ cord to 41-2o — tops in the NBA - trailed 9o-88 with 7:55 to go in the final period. 
But before 
Detroit could score again with 24 seconds remaining in the game, the Nuggets had rolled up 2o straight points. 
A basket by Dan Issei tied the game at 9o-9o before Thompson erupt­ ed for three straight bas­ kets. Bobby Jones hit a free throw , Issei a basket and Ted McClain another two-pointer before 
Thompson whipped in seven consecutive points to turn the game into a runaway.

ATLANTA (A P ) - A late Atlanta rally fell short Tuesday night as the Los Angeles Lakers, paced by Hareem Ab- dul-Jabbar’s 24 points, defeated the Hawks 92-9o in NBA action. 
With 3:28 left in the contest, the Lakers led 
89-8o. But the Hawks, us­ ing balanced scoring, put in IO straight to take a 
9o-89 lead, their first since early in the first period. 
Cazzie Russell hit 
12-foot jumper for Los 
Angeles with 28 seconds left to put his team ahead 
91-9o. With 19 seconds remaining. John Drew fumbled the ball out of bounds and turned it over to the Lakers
