SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— W ednesday March 2 1977 
Fast-improving Rangers on schedule 

The San 
Antonio 
College 
Rangers started out slower than the infamous tortoise this sea­ son. 

Bul it you don't watch out. the 
Rangers may still win the race. 
There is no question Hon Culpep­ per's team has advanced with greater strides than an antelope Never mind that SAC ended its season Monday night, losing to Temple. Sl-fiH, in the 
Region X IV South Zone Tournament. 
SAC was expected to have its uniforms encased in moth halls by the time the playoffs rolled around. 
Fast finish 
The Rangers, who have only two so­ phomores on their 15-man roster, nearly self-destructed in their first two games of the season. SAC lost to Hill 
County, 1o2-57, and McLennan of Waco, 
o1-56. 
Instead of folding its tent. SAC went about building a bigger and better fortress. By season s end. the Rangers had improved a 1-5 start to a 14-16 mark and qualified for the post-season tourney for the first time under the top four format. 
With 13 returning performers. Cul­ pepper is ecstatic about the possibi­ lities of next season. 
“ It all came out the way I had it planned," said Culpepper. "It s not often that it happens that way. I felt I 

College Scene 

 w i t h ( ' l i f f o r d B r o y l e s 

 had the right kind of kids who would respond, and in this case. I read the kids right." 
"These guys are only .inst begin­ ning," he continued. "A ll of their car­ eers are still ahead of them. If we continue to work, then we're going to unstoppable." 
Come now. Coach! Let’s not exag­ gerate.. Are you sure the word you want it unstoppable.’’ 
"W e have lim itations,” admitted 
Culpepper. "B u t this bunch will be able to do so many things to overcome 
Biose limitations" 
Few scholarships 

Quoting from a pre-season roundup in the Express, Culpepper said last 
November, "Quite honestly we’re not going to go 3o-o. We're shooting for conference.” 
With 13 freshmen back, not many scholarships w ill be available this 

 time. Culpepper has put a priority on a playmaking guard and a big man. 
"I want a guard who can break the man XX press," he emphasized. "And 
I d like one big man to help us get on the boards a little better.” 
Perhaps the No. I quality of this SAC team is its brinny substance. I>ast year 
Culpepper lost four regulars to grade problems at mid-term. 
He vowed to avoid such pitfalls if possible in the future and he took extra care in selecting his latest group of prospects because of it . 

All are still around and the little things are beginning to fall into place, piece by piece. 
"Because of their intelligence level, they'll be able to make a lot of teams play their game,” said Culpepper. "If we can continue to improve then that will be one of our strengths — making the other team play our game. 

" If we went out. today and ran with 
Hill or McLennan they would still pro­ bably bent us, but if we make them play our game they won t be quite as tough.” 
Culpepper, reiterated time and again during the season, that it was essential that his team keep its head up in the face of advery. 
“ I've had better records." he said, 
"but as far as satisfaction goes, this is the best year I ve had in college coaching.” he said. 
" I ve had young men with good atti­ tudes but with this group you don't have to command it or demand it. 
They give it to you.” 
Culpepper looked down his bench and put in a word for Toro Martinez and Gay land Fisher, the two seldom- used sophomores for the Rangers. 
Fisher has not played in the last eight games and Martinez plays a little in most. 
"When you look at the job our so­ phomores have done and their atti­ tudes it s been outstanding,” said Cul­ pepper. 
’’They’ve contributed as much as any starter in their own way. 
Gayland hasn t played in eight games and and never complains and keeps giving IOO per cent all the time. That's putting attitude to the test.” 
Individually 
Culpepper thinks sharpshooter Billy Bailey "is one of the two best freshmen" in the league and 6-7 Mike Wollmers is another po­ 

 tential big timer. 
Ben Click and Neil McLellan have also made substantial contributions in starting roles while 6-8 Lann Sawyer has made the most improvement on 

 the team. 
Now that the season is over, Culpep­ per plans to give his team a week of rest then begin work on the off-season program which leads to next season.
